title: Great company, great pay, solid customer base, ample sales opportunities
pros: Lots of great supportive people who are more customer focused than other tech giants I have worked for. The offer I accepted was higher than I had expected for my experience level (Around $100k base / $100k comm for Enterprise AE role with 10 yrs B2B exp.). Lots of selling tools, a dedicated CSM (vital to your success), a shared SDR, and a shared SME for each major product category. Customers generally like us, are easy to engage with and accept meeting requests. Competitive offerings with lots to upsell within accounts across other departments and LOBs.. The products are competitive and sufficiently suited for customers' needs,
cons: It can be easy to get stuck in discussions about legacy paper-based services that customers know Iron Mountain for (offsite records storage and doc shredding are their bread and butter). While there is a big opportunity for converting these legacy customers to digital services, Iron Mountain has most room to grow in it's cloud, digitization, and digital storage businesses. Nearly all sales are generated within existing customers who have large offsite storage accounts already, by forming relationships with the right people to find new projects, expansions, and renewal upsells. Frequent account team changes and annual rep reassignments seem to have the most damaging impact to these relationships. Rarely are deals won from a position of clear product superiority or lowest price, but rather from trusted relationships with the customer's AE and account team.

title: Awesome place to learn and grow
pros: I was recruited to join Iron Mountain a year ago. When first contacted I thought, "the shredding company?" which is a common misperception. Iron Mountain is so much more. Our Matterhorn growth and transformation story is awe-inspiring and to be able to be even one sentence of one page of one chapter of that growth story makes me feel like I'm having an immense impact. Not to mention the Head of Executive Search and the Head of Talent Acquisition are 2 of the best bosses I've had in my 20+ year career. They really know the industry and the talent function, and have the patience to impart what they know in a meaningful and resonant way. I am beyond blessed to have joined such a great team and am delighted to be able to help recruit some of the best and brightest executives to join our climb.
cons: The organization is growing and changing so rapidly that (1) sometimes it is hard to keep up with what each of the business units are doing which can be challenging when trying to tell the full IRM story and (2) there are internal transitions that are part of the growing pains of an organization undergoing this much transformation.

title: Learning Experience -- Learn to Leave
pros: There seem to be a few "current" Iron Mountain (IRM) employees who have nothing but glowing and polished remarks about working there; they would give the company ten stars if they could. Not at all suspicious, right? Anyway, from my experience as a former employee: Telework options are still a wonderful thing here, at least for the corporate office. The salary offer is sweet draw (for me, pre-pandemic, it was). Even the health insurance seemed great, but I don't know for sure because I never had time to use it except to get flu and anti-COVID shots.
cons: A lot of the glowing reviews, here, seem planted and/or were probably incentivized. Yes, for the most part, IRM people are friendly and sociable and somewhat active on employee resource groups (ERG), which aim to represent nearly every identity; but participating in ERG events, meetings and presentations takes extra time and extra voluntary work on top of unpaid work on top of your salaried job... all of which add to negative work-life balance. The micromanagement is subtle but real, right down to their social media monitoring habits. I don't know about the C-Suite backgrounds, but based on some people who I've engaged with, the employees who have been with the company for more than 10yrs are senior leaders who are likely still there because they previously were with a company that IRM acquired; they're usually the only ones that remained after the acquisition. I hope these corporate veterans at least were given do-not-fire types of contracts until retirement. If you want to stay with IRM for 25+ years, start your own company and get acquired by IRM. This company is focused on and all about mergers, acquisitions, corporate politics /favoritism and accommodating the shareholders. The culture is patronizing, at best, with some passive-aggressive superiority complexes. The small talk from higher ranks and meeting "icebreakers" are sad and disingenuous; there's no talking to some of these high ranks unless you're agreeing with them and/or stroking their egos. It wasn't an overtly stuffy environment, but many elements of a toxic one exist here. It wasn't a good or healthy vibe for me.

title: Not a good to place to work.
pros: Ability to take individual ideas and develop them into corporate contributions.
cons: Very staid organization, business model based on holding client's data hostage, antiquated business systems, does not embrace change. But all of that could be easily forgiven, because, hey, what large company isn't resistant to change and straddled with inefficient business systems, but the low overall review is due almost solely to what I saw as extreme intellectual arrogance. Top management truly believe they have invented the better mousetrap and are just smarter than everyone else in B2B outsourced business services. When in reality, their customers just don't have any other option. They are the Cable Company of information management services, slow, poor customer service, over-priced and not truly providing the product the customer actually needs. They're a storage company first and foremost, so their message of managing inventory through a life-cycle, through a finite point, is mostly lip service. Once they have the data, they have no intention of destroying it for them once the data is no longer needed, as that destroys their recurring revenue model, and much of their revenue is driven by customers who do not want to pay the charges to pull the storage from their warehouses - many customers simply walk away from their storage rather than pay the check out charges. Quite a few of their customers can't stand Iron Mountain because they hold a commodity service offering up as a premium product and price gauge, 58% margins for basic storage means the customer obviously has no other choice. As technologies change, they will see their margins and customer loyalty suffer, they have it coming.

Supervisors play favorotes, take advantage of workers who don't speak up when abused, yet punish workers who do speak up via the "open door" policy. Upper management is out of touch with those in the trenches, and spends more resources on fluff and things that don't matter, as opposed to things that do and that would actually meet goals. Everything they do regarding policy is very self-defeating, contradictory, and they never realize it until its too late and they create even more policies to attempt to reconcile the negative affects of past policy. This company is not competitive, and only survives due to its size, share of the market, and ability to absorb its competition.

There are also a lot of great managers who care about their employees' well-beings and development. There has been significant growth and development in onboarding, training, and learning opportunities. The vast majority of employees who are tasked with executing the daily responsibilities of servicing our customers have our core values in their souls (they bleed Iron Mountain blue and security is #1).
cons: Their has been a lot of change in strategic directions from the top, and while change is good and important, many high-level decisions have been reversed in a few years, or even within a year. Some decisions and changes are evolutions and are merely adjustments, but some have been major reversals. This creates a great deal of insecurity with our employees. There are quite a few bad seeds in the exempt, support workforce that have no accountability. Managers are not universally strong and your success depends on the competency of your manager, which is not always good. Too much specialization without the encouragement/nurture of broadening understanding and teamwork means that the gray areas (the undefined responsibilities that don't have a "specialist" assigned to perform it) become the burden of a dedicated but overworked few.

That equates to ~$300M Total Contract Value, or $15M TCV per person.

title: Detached Management
pros: Regular hours, okay benefits/time off. It was nice to get a reward for five years of service.
cons: Compensation weak to average. Office was a haven of gossip and backstabbing that was never addressed by management. Enjoyed the people I worked with, but when new management came in they forced out, for no apparent reason other than the new manager didn't like her, a 9-year employee who was a stellar worker and had irreplaceable depth of knowledge. It was incredibly disheartening to see such treatment to someone who had been so loyal. New manager immediately disregarded everything we had been doing in order to adopt more uniform Iron Mountain procedures without bothering to discover why our customized systems existed or how they functioned. New schedules were created and employees asked to request the days off they preferred, with the implication that senior employees would receive first choice. I was the most senior employee at the time, but was given my last choice, and was told it was because I knew too much so the office needed me on the day off I'd requested. I left not long after that.

title: Project Manager
pros: Overall, co-workers were intelligent and wanted to do their jobs well, with some exceptions. The benefits plan was reasonably good for a large company.
cons: Layoffs, layoffs, off-shoring and more layoffs. No career path. Raises are meager. Even if you are rated well in a review the percentage bump is barely at the rate of inflation. A revolving door in the management ranks means they don’t stick with a strategy for more than 6 months. Layoffs became routine in the last 4-5 years. There was an underlying culture of fear as people began to worry that they would be next on the chopping block. In many cases layoff decisions appeared to be based on political alliances or the need to fulfill a diversity profile rather than being based on experience, knowledge and contributions. Many internal support and IT positions were moved offshore to India and other countries. This began as a gradual transition that gained momentum. This had an impact on efficiency, quality and most of all, customer satisfaction. Senior Executives express pride in the fact that they can pay an offshore Engineer 60% less than a U.S. worker. Constant reorganization and shift in business strategy. A new initiative would be announced and it would quietly go away after 6 to 9 months. In some areas of the company people will only do the minimum of what is asked of them and not look at the bigger picture and what is good for the customer. Bureaucratic decision making process, silo mentality and lack of accountability. Archaic backend enterprise technology. The company was built by acquisition and many of the backend systems are cobbled together remnants of those acquisitions.

title: Transportation Router 1

cons: Job stability is lacking on a local level due to budget problems for the local territory. Local management team is diificult to work with due to their inability to accept change and innovative ideas. Safety programs were in place through the company yet on the local level safety was not a concern and it was evident in all equipment used on a daily basis which was in need of major repairs. Employees were often scheduled so tight with their work flow breaks were often untaken. Benefits ,all though abundant, can be hard to get and make changes to based on unrealistic deadlines specifically if one has a life event that requires government paperwork.

title: IM used to be a great company!
pros: 5-10 years ago, Iron Mountain was an excellent company to work for. They valued their employees and ideas. Listening to the former CEO (Richard Reese) speak was extremely motivating and always made us proud to work there, and excited to do our part. It wasn't about politics, it was about doing a great job and taking good care of our customers.
cons: More recently, Iron Mountain became the worst of the worst in corporate ineffectual bureaucratic management incompetence. People are rewarded/promoted for doing a bad job. Management has no clue what their employees do on a daily basis. Employees are not valued. After sitting through speeches by CEO Bob Brennan, you feel like you have been in church, reprimanded and beaten down with fire and brimstone. When times get tough, they fire employees and add a couple layers of mgmt instead of adding people to actually help with the workload. It is ALL about politics. The management team has preconceived notions that they believe are true, regardless of employee/customer opinions and experiences PROVING otherwise.

title: Great in some ways but not enough to justify the effort
pros: An exciting and (somewhat) progressive culture Wonderful, vibrant, enthusiastic people to work with Adventurous and productive sales environment A GREAT set of services and solutions First-rate brand recognition and trust in the marketplace Training is first rate Benefits are top notch
cons: The salary is FAR beneath the effort and expertise it takes to do the job well--you will work your tail off and wonder why your paycheck is never what it should be Commission structure is difficult to understand, track and quanitfy--for the effort that's demanded it's hard to fathom that you must chase your commissions to make sure you are paid on everything Upper management doesn't disclose the unfair pay structure--in fact, they oversell the OTE Everything depends on the manager you have--no consistency in style, it's just all numbers, all the time Customer Service should be a completely different department--it's impossible to achieve these numbers with the amount of non-commissionable tasks they require you to perform. This is the BIGGEST liability of the job--there is never enough time to actually sell

title: Nice while it lasted
pros: People in the trenches are typically good, loyal employees. Great brand recognition for paper & tape storage. Comp is fair. great location in Boston. If you are an efficiency expert and can help improve efficiencies and reduce head count you might enjoy the company.
cons: Many people in Senior management are in place from acquisitions. There is too much loyalty to leaders who should have been let go long ago. (excluding H. Ebbighausen, he is probably the best leader there) Otherwise big old boy network. Since acquiescing to the demands of the Elliott Group the company has given up on the Digital growth strategy, or any growth strategy it seems. Mistakes were made in Digital but could have been fixed. Marketing is poorly run and grossly under-funded. 401K contribution limit is low for high earners because majority of employees are not making that much. Max out around $15K before they have to send your money back to you..

title: Director Business Development
pros: Large company. Good employees especially the customer facing group. There is a great deal of talent.
cons: Iron Mountain is becoming a REIT and that trumps everything. Mass layoff in Q4 of customer facing associates and the restructuring is just starting. The customer facing unit of Iron Mountain is very uncertain of their future and lacking confidence in what Senior Leadership is telling them. At the end of the day Iron Mountain will look very different moving into 2014. Look for more downsizing and the selling off of Service related revenue streams as the company moves back to its core of boxes in wherehouses. It is a difficult time to be an Iron Mountain employee if you are in Sales or Account Management. This is a true example of big business. The corporation will do what it intends to and this makes it a tough time to be in the rank and file.

title: Run...unless you're a BFF of a Director!
pros: Investors will be happy when the company reaches REIT. If you like to watch "Game of Thrones," you can play a real life version working here.
cons: Just about everything else. The company prides itself on promotions, but they are just title elevations. Brown nosing is encouraged. When people leave, no one gets promoted to the actual vacant role, except for the sycophants, and even then it is only if the director or VP does not have a friend they want to give the job to. Interviews are a dog and pony show; management knows whom they want to hire, despite how under qualified or incompetent they are. People are asked to leave when they voice disagreements. Lost of intradepartment feuding when a senior person leaves as each director strives to make their team look good and everyone else look bad. You can tell who is losing because he or she will jump ship and let his or her underlings be reassigned to the conquering manager.

title: Be careful
pros: Pay is above average, anyone not in management was great to work with, customers were great! Bonus/incentive program was usually good but it changed every year. Expectations/focus of the company was also constantly changing
cons: Management has little concern for customers concerns and rarley listens to you when you try to point out probelms, Denver management has an attitude of superiority and little respect for "worker bees" Expectation is that you work whatever hours are necessary including at night and on weekends just to keep up. Customer billing concerns are a total NIGHTMARE and impossible to fix (manager is little help.) There is definetly favortism amoung senior leadership as to who will get promoted an who won't and who will get help when they need it and how much.

title: Was once a great place to work, but not anymore.
pros: Good location and nice new physical work environment Flexibility to work from home Good people to work with if you don't count management
cons: The place has become very political since the hiring of the current CEO in early 2013. He, himself, is almost never around and is really very detached from the business. He spends more time flying back to Asia (where he was based for 25 years) or to Australia for weeks at a time to attend board meetings of Qantas Airlines. He is also very quick to spend the company's money so that he can fly on private planes or attend the World Economic Forum in Switzerland, while at the same time people are being laid off left and right. He has placed responsibility for the company strategy with an executive whose background is in Human Resources. Nobody knows where the company is going from one day to the next. Career advancement is not good unless you are one of the favored few.

title: If you like long-term commitment, it will work out.
pros: People are lively and for the most part both fun and competent. There are areas where you wonder how people got/keep their jobs, but mostly it's good. Morale is quite high since divesting the Digital unit and re-instatement of Richard Reese. You can advance here quite nicely and make a good lliving, but it takes a while. If you want to be a shooting star, this is not the place for you. If you don't mind waiting a while until you have proven yourself, you will do fine. In the past year, there has been emphasis on management training and power messaging, and you can feel the difference for the better.
cons: At times it feels insanely disorganized. None of the sytems are connected to each other and actual policies can be hard to find. The benefits are lean, especially for a company of this size. I think for new people it can be hard. The company is not the best at orienting and welcoming new people, promotions do seem to come slowly, but the company is doing a much better job of utilizing talent efficiently.

title: Awesome Company to work for!!!!
pros: Having been at Iron Mountain for over 22 years, I have enjoyed working for this company and value the relationships I have made here. Iron Mountain values their employees/staff. They know that a happy employee is a steadfast employee that will work hard for the company and the brand. I enjoy all the perks being a Mountaineer has provided me and my family. From the great benefits for Healthcare, vision, dental to all the wonderful opportunities for saving on College for my kids, 401K for my future, and many perks to save on auto/home insurance and many, many others.
cons: The only con that I have to offer is that many positions with the new landscape are now work remotely, and the challenge to that is you are never off or away from your computer/work. Me personally, I don't mind that and it helps me keep up, however that can be a con if you are not use to that, or havent worked remotely before.

title: A good career but the company is becoming a little stagnant.
pros: The company offers decent compensation with a nice benefits package including healthcare. Training for new hires is thorough and they provide strong sales support.
cons: There has been a lot of trial and error over the recent past. They dabbled in digital solutions by buying various companies in the digital backup space but then sold them off. The foundation of the business is paper storage and they are by far the largest service provider. The problem is that they already have most of the largest clients so growth from those is minimal. Raises haven't come to existing sales personnel for extended periods and in some cases for many years. The CEO of more than 30 years just retired. Not sure what effect that will have. He was one of the best.

title: Not as stable as they use to be! Horrible culture and upper management.
pros: Good benefits and flexible hours.
cons: Horrible culture and upper management. Records center jobs are the worst in the business, with transportation a close second. Turnover is really high due to the lack of employees. Utilize a lot of temporary workers which can be difficult on FTE's. In 3 years, I've seen 6 Operations managers fired or resigned and 9 supervisors. This is not normal for any company. Two layoffs in the last 2 years while broadening work assignments. Inventory system runs on DOS. Training is bad for a company this size, not structured, basically your at the mercy of someone else while they perform their normal job. Production measurements for labor or not accurate and unrealistic for employees who work in the record centers.

title: Transportation Supervisor
pros: Decent resume builder. You will learn a lot as they force many duties on you as they cut and don’t replace positions.
cons: Upper management has no clue of the frontline workforce. It is purely based on numbers some engineer with no experience made up. It’s all chasing numbers with no care towards customer service or employee retainment. Last 5 years has been all cuts and downsizing. They use temporary employees mostly. Records management Is just about dead as digital and going green is every company goal. Biggest area of growth is shred, which is basically making you a garbage man. Total over emphasis on dumb side tasks they come up with over customer satisfaction.

title: Watch out, this is not the old Iron Mountain, things have drastically changed in the past few years.
pros: There are many offices locations across the country which allows relocation while staying with the same employer. There are some excellent managers that are mentors who also promote growth opportunities.
cons: The local top management. These folks care nothing about the employees, they act as though they are un-touchable. There is a "boys club" that you can't penetrate, these employees hurt so much more than they help. Management by bulling. STOP HIRING YOUR RELATIVES and giving them the opportunities that should be opened to everyone.

title: RC Coordinator 17 years
pros: Good health benefits, quarterly bonus and pay is above the national average.
cons: This place will destroy you physically and mentally. Long hours; 14-16 it's very normal since they run skeleton crews. Jobs that were done by 10-12 to people are now done by 2 or 3 employees. Heavy work; permanent back injuries is normal for anyone working after there 5 years. It's normal for a person to lift 40lb boxes 500 times in one day shift. Management; Every hourly employee has hourly quotas to fill and you can get written up for failing those numbers. They have 'stealth layoff's' almost every year; they will get ride of the old timers slowly so they can increase their profit margin.

title: Unstable Management
pros: Benefits,401k,Vacation. Paid holidays,Overtime available if you want to work it
cons: Pay grade is not compatible for today's market. $13.25 for a new hire doesn't bring potential employees in to work. Supervisor told me recently that he's gonna do whatever it takes to protect his position. I replied that's not teamwork even though you guys preach fake Code of Ethics. Manager doesn't even know about record center because he come from shred dept. PMT is so stupid because only 2 people in building. So called sentinel coach get paid to train but regular employee get stuck with task. Only get shirt for uniform now. Took bonuses away, not sure about next review. Seem like company hurting for money even though management still increasing their wages. More to say but short time.

title: Glad to have had the experience, but even happier to have moved on
pros: The thing that worked for me was that I got to work on things up to a certain point. It helped me learn more things. The telecommuting was a wonderful thing as being in the office was stressful and uncomfortable. If you are looking to hide in a corner and do a limited amount of work then this is the place for you.
cons: Departments are very territorial and each team is looking out for themselves. A lot of finger pointing, but not a lot of accomplishments (They haven't learned about "united we stand, divided we fall".) Directors like to use jargon without much thought as to how things can be done. No clear vision.

title: Good Money, clueless CEO
pros: Great Pay - they have to pay well, else talent wont come to them Great work-life - Most people have 9-5 schedules, or work remotely Nice office location Perks - coffee, Quarterly Pizza, beer etc.
cons: CEO is disengaged. He has "broken" the company into small pieces, created fiefdoms and let those people rule. Problem is "those" people are not leaders, are not smart. The head of a major BU was a truck driver - and see where the revenue and earning of that group is going. CEO flies private, while we have to pinch every expense. They have a VERY HARD time recruiting executives. CEO search took 2 yrs. CMO - 4 and still counting. Head of a major BU - 1 yr. No accomplished exec wants to touch w a 10 ft pole. Huge salary disparities - I knew Sr. Managers making 75K as well as 155K base. --> Come on guys be fair.

title: Management
pros: Decent pay/Decent work life balance, good benefits. My direct management team cared about its employees. It used to be a great company to work for until the last few years. Times are a changing.
cons: Company has a new CEO....just like in the manufacturing industry Iron mountain is selling out its US employee base to cheaper off shore labor. Company cannot for the life of itself figure out how to properly manage its account base. Good luck on getting a promotion....they are in a non hiring death spiral. This is a no growth industry....and this company cannot seem to diversify.

title: Tough Job
pros: As a landscaper, you work the entire eight hours doing strenuous activities and projects. Most of the staff was nice (expect for a few who were abrasive and, to be honest, a little cruel), and the day's objectives were laid out clearly.
cons: The pay is minimum wage, which is worth it if you don't mind physical labor. I, for one, loved the work. Sure, it was tough, but it was satisfying. The main complaint I have is that staff members weren't allowed to listen to anything on headphones throughout the day. When you're weedeating for eight hours straight, what would be the problem if you listened to a podcast or something. In fact, you couldn't even have your phone. Considering that some of the work had the potential for danger (near a lake, snakes, sharp objects, intense heat) I don't know how smart it is to not allow you to have cell phones.

title: You are a worker bee, don’t expect more
pros: I honestly can’t think of any. I’d you like working mandatory overtime foe the money, then I guess that’s a pro.
cons: No consideration for your personal life or your safety during covid. Mandatory overtime and weekends to meet production standards that are not achievable due to management dropping the ball and processes that need to be improved. As an employee you are expected to be a worker bee. Your opinion does not matter. Your fear of covid does not matter. Your process ideas do not matter. Also no parking and no phones allowed on the work floor. Get used to warehouse rules even though this was a mortgage office before Iron Mountain took over.

title: Not a challenging place to work
pros: Benefits are excellent. Co workers are generally nice and team oriented. Work-life balance is good. Easy commute. Good corporate citizen.
cons: Senior leadership is too entrenched and has no idea where they are taking the company (although they say they do). They finally got fresh ideas in with an outside CEO only to replace him with a former long term CEO. In general management is of poor quality. Very old technology - failed at their digital business and have regressed back to paper storage and electronic scanning (dinosaur). Company is going in circles but doesn't realize it. Seems to be a collection bin for average and sub-par employees.

title: The other side of the Mountain.
pros: There are some perks to working for the company. We are awarded balloons and $5.00 gift cards for going "above and beyond". The entire floor looks like a day care--how embarrassing!!!
cons: When there is instability in senior leadership, the worst is bound to happen and it has. Change is constantly happening, the two headquartered locations are never on the same accord with anything and are to mirror each other. The tools given to us to utilize throughout the course of a day is outdated and slow which quite naturally slows down production. Mostly all department managers and supervisors are all over the place with no formal mechanical training for the environment. The selection process should be a lot tighter. Its not a matter of the experience or education they bring in with them, it is what they are applying that is not a strong fit. It is bringing the department down and is probably why turnover is so high.

title: Give credit where credit is due
pros: Great people!  Have been presented with plenty of opportunity over the years (21 years).  Flexible schedule as a transportation supervisor.  Good direct manager.  Love my employees.  Good benefits and programs.  Lots of opportunity if you want it.
cons: LONG HOURS.  Little recognition for doing good work.  Completely metrics driven these days, which creates a disconnect when it comes to the people side of management.   Holding a team accountable is one thing, but things are getting a bit out of control now.  No time to work along side your employees, mainly just analyzing metrics and answering to analysts that don't know the job.  Not a lot of upward mobility locally as most of upper management has been around for years.

title: Don't expect to advance
pros: - Stable job (however, there have been lots of layoffs) - Nice people, and some want to make a difference and improve the company
cons: - People aren't promoted based on quality of work -- it's mostly a game of favorites. If you like playing politics, or don't mind not being promoted ever, Iron Mountain is the place for you. - The performance review process is a total farce. Again -- it's the favorites who get rated highly. The hard workers who do a stellar job but don't play politics get the short end of the stick. People are rated on a bell curve, which is nonsense and brutal on morale. - Tons of work; people are expected to do the work of 2+ people. I was at IRM for the better part of a decade, and I saw this play out time and time again.

title: Excellent place to work
pros: Used to be great place work for more than 9 years, lot of new technologies were introduced until 2007 and fast paced. Excellent CEO that time guiding the company during good and bad time was Richard. I always admirred and proud at work there and he is back again and things will definitely will get better.
cons: ultant

title: Only a matter of time
pros: Decent pay, Well known, Nice Uniforms
cons: Poor Insurance considering their "purchasing power." They love to hire military and not smart military which is the problem. If they set metrics for mid-level area staff they would see how dumb and how little they are needed. I work here 8 years as a supervisor and have been refused 3x for a higher position for someone who painted vehicles in the military. I had a degree in Business Management and the new manager didnt. Click? Oh yes. I heard a manager once call it the "dumb d!*k click!" They will fall hard and soon.

title: High expectations and lacks the tools and bodies to get the job done effectively.
pros: Team members are a great group of employees. Work areas are clean, climate controlled and they offer a decent benefits package for full time employees.
cons: The work load is excessive for the amount of people on the team. I understand metrics, employee performance and maximizing productivity but Iron Mountain takes these methods too far in my opinion. For a company that consistently generates revenue, it would not hurt the bottom line to hire some more employees rather than work the existing ones to death.

title: This company could be great but it's not yet
pros: They are defintely the leader in their industry. They have a solid foundation of facilities and support. Working for a large corporation you get good benefits. They offer a good employee stock purchase plan as well. The training is much better than it has been in the past.
cons: Lack of long term vision. Not very many advancement opportunities for top performers. The middle manangement has been in place too long and they seem to retread the same people in different positions. They have become stagnant from the last ten years of being successful. You have a large target on your back from the competetion.

title: politics
pros: Solid org and products are sustainable so no fear of the company folding. Pays the bills ( starts around 12hr) , offers health life and 401 benefits plus two weeks vacation from the beginning. The atmosphere was like high school with micromanagers being manipulative and playing games instead of assisting reps with customers, I have a friend who still works there however and says it has improved a bit
cons: you will be told you can advance anywhere you have background experience within six months but this is only true for favorites. Most supervisors don't know the job and have a do as I say not as I do attitude, in fact many were simply facebook friends of some higher staff member and mysteriously moved up while the phone reps are the forefront and first to assist customers.

title: Thanks for the 16 years of Service, but we don't need you anymore.
pros: The Frontline teammates are the backbone, eyes and ears of this company. I worked with some outstanding people who took/take pride in getting the job done and providing great Customer Service and Feedback.
cons: Seems most everyone with "Manager" in their title has lost touch with those who actually do the work. Yeah, they try to roll out programs/initiatives to show they care or have a clue, but these roll outs soon lose steam and are forgotten, along with the valuable feedback the frontline people could provide them. The intelligence of the frontline people is definitely underestimated by Management. Micro Managed until your eyes pop out. Seem to have Cutbacks almost yearly. It's all about the bottom dollar, not the loyal employee.

title: They talk the talk, but fail to walk the walk.
pros: Location Nice Office There are still a few good people left Flexible hour Work from home option
cons: With the company's most recent efforts of digital transformation it traded in its integrity to reinvent itself. Nepotism, name calling, degrading, bullying and deceitful behavior is not only tolerated, but also supported by leadership and senior members of the SET. People are no longer an important asset, they are a mere end to the means. Human Resources is outsourced oversees, training is non existent, the on-boarding process for new hires consists of watching a bunch of videos and doing the necessary online trainings to stay compliant. If you need help, open a ticket. Welcome to Iron Mountain ! There is ZERO communication, managers lie, deceive and bully - and everything is tolerated, as long as it serves the greater goal.

title: Great Company to work for if you're not in IT
pros: Company are constantly challenging themselves to improve Good opportunities to grow within the organization
cons: New leadership in technology especially the CTO are changing the culture in a bad way by managing by shame - public reprimands are now common and people are afraid to raise concerns for fear of the new 'shoot the messenger' mentality. The culture within IT has become toxic and no longer matches with the rest of the organization. Still a good company to work for if you are not part of the Technology team.

title: Formerly happy but as time went on much had changed
pros: Leader in industry, New CEO, Purchase the Competition, Excellent Benefit Package
cons: Workalike Balance, Mid Level Management (Tenured and lack enthusiasm and will oppose companies core values if it benefits them or keeps them employed), job security (restructures or layoffs in last 3 years)

title: It went from great to mediocre, mainly due to changes in management.
pros: It is a stable company, it offers good benefits, it looks good on your resume, you could potentially work with Fortune 1000 companies.
cons: Due to changes in management that were no longer technology savvy, I experienced serious drawbacks in my final days. My manager was uncooperative in helping me working out some silly glitches in my paperwork which caused me considerable amount of trouble. I figured it all out eventually, but having worked at a company for 6 years with impeccable record, one would imagine, they would be more helpful.

title: if you can make it here... you can make it anywhere
pros: good technologies, supportive of remote work environments
cons: EXTREMELY political, hard to survive. A ton of command and conquer attitudes. It all depends on who you work for, but everyone is driving the bus here. More time spent on protecting yourself rather than fixing an issue. emails from a year ago count even though requirements change. Personally i would say enter at your own risk. Be ready for layoffs each year. Stay low profile

title: Not what it used to be....in a BAD way.
pros: Benefits package is decent. Pay is above average as it would be hard to go out into the job market and make comparable pay.
cons: Poor Management. Inconsistent enforcement of policies...definitely some favoritism involved. Management is lacking in the "people skills" area. When they actually acknowledge you, they talk at you, not to you. Management has tendencies to be two-faced...smiling and polite to those above them on the food chain, but horribly routinely rude to frontline employees and supervisors. It's the only company I know that has one hour meetings to prepare for a half hour meeting. Accountability is preached by management, but they are first to "redirect" the blame off themselves.

title: Good Company
pros: Pay and Benefits are good. The coworkers are good guys to work with.
cons: Supervisors fail to communicate with each other on things that are going on. This than causes problems. Some who are in leadership roles should not have that position, do to not qualified or do not want to do their job properly. Some others like to just blow smoke up your butt. Like to make promises and don't keep them. Like one time my coworkers and I were promise a gift card for Thanksgiving by our supervisor, that was 5 months ago now and we have yet to receive them. Trying to get our yearly uniforms is another issue. Takes months to get supplies need to do the job, and only than because we keep asking.

title: Admirable Vision…Struggles with Strategy to Execution
pros: Iron Mountain is in the midst of transformational change and striving to augment the traditional business lines with complementary offerings such as asset lifecycle management and digital transformation offerings. They are serious about this transformation and it has the potential to be an exciting journey.
cons: The company is still finding their way in regards to how best to lead transformational change. The change management practices of the senior leadership team are lacking. It is very much a command and control leadership structure that is not empowering of the mid level leadership team. Decisions affecting teams are made without appropriate inclusion of the leaders of impacted teams.

title: They love to off-shore their IT. Corporate greed abounds. Poor moral compass.
pros: Big company so plenty of room to grow unless you get stuck under an oppressive manager. Salary was satisfactory.
cons: Their talent was not the best and brightest, but they have weeded so many people out that maybe it has improved. Poor job security. They chop heads any chance they get. Very cheap company. Don't expect a lot of perks because they are not spenders on their employees. They are not loyal and will cut people in a heart beat. Paper storage will eventually die.

title: Territory Operations Leader in North America
pros: Without question the dedicated, long-term, front-line employees. These are truly amazing people; proud of their work, attitude and commitment.
cons: For over 5 years the company has reduced corporate staff, leadership and FT front-line staff. High turnover related to the required utilization of temp employees puts a significant strain on the entire organization. Inordinate downward pressure applied to the NA Records Management business line which is significantly suffering as the world moves away from paper. IM will implode before it explodes.

title: Organized Chaos
pros: If you land in the right group, the people are fantastic.
cons: There is no defined process for many of the departments here. There is a lot going on, but it is tough to identify anyone who can define how a process works or a policy is carried out. Organized chaos, because somehow things appear to be getting done, but on the back end, you truly never know who is doing what at the company. Very frustrating environment to get these rolled out, and a lot of people nay-saying before they understand what they are so passionately saying no to. Not enough room for growth or true developmental change.

title: Okay Company to Work For
pros: Culture,
cons: istency, Professional Client Support, Nimble Flat Organization, Decent Bonuses

title: Good company but too much change too quickly
pros: Wonderful co-workers who cared about being successful, not just guarding their own territory. Strong commitment to developing managers. Very supportive of employees' personal needs. Caring and compassionate, for the most part. Nice severance package.
cons: Rapid change means top talent was laid off. Top management not all that candid about their vision. Increased offshoring, meaning more job loss, when not that long ago, the company prided itself on having local help desk support for customers and employees. Company is being run to impress shareholders, but this impacts the quality of service and morale.

title: Okay pay over worked
pros: They allow you to use the company vehicle to take CDL driving test
cons: They over work you on a daily basis. You call for help if they don't have it you're on your own. But they expect you to call in to see if anyone else needs help before you can go home. Every day if you are new your load will be the hardest as a courier. If you complain about your work load they will give you more work.

title: Company Review
pros: A few select Diversity Leaders attempting to make a change.
cons: Steeped in a culture of long term leaders lacking integrity and professional maturity. Leaders promoted beyond knowledge and LEADER capabilities. Leaders taking credit for the work of others. Favoritism that is reinforced by executive leaders. Those who challenge the status quo of the favorites find themselves on the outside often verbally confronted in a demeaning and insulting manner. Leads to great employees feeling restricted in being able to be effective in their jobs. It makes for an unfulfilling, immoral and hostile environment. A Players will leave in search of a company where they can be greater contributors in a inclusive environment.

title: Transportation Supervisor
pros: Really good fellow supervisors! Great drivers that will do what you ask most of the time. Fun bunch of guys. Benefits are a plus.
cons: Shred managers will make supervisors do their dirty work. They will lie to your face and walk around the corner and say something totally different to an hourly driver. I've seen it 1st hand. They will preach safety but when an issue arises this particular manager will say "that's your problem. Come back to me with a solution!" He will act like your best friend when the director is in town but will stab you in the back as soon as he leaves. This is in the Houston office on the shred side. The hard copy side has a bunch of really good guys. Stay away from shred manager(s). They will do whatever it takes to look good on paper. Even if it cost you our job! This particular manager will not allow you a work/life balance. It doesn't exist with him.

title: Watched company fka. IO go downhill rapidly.
pros: If you like corporate you'll be right at home.
cons: Iron Mountain bought out IO in January of 2018. Once July rolled around, the transition started and with every other passing week a new rule would become implemented that spectacularly lowered the quality of work life in the data center. The micromanagement was unbearable, and the managers themselves are highly toxic, consisting of yes men, busy bodies and people who are just downright trying their hardest to catch you doing anything wrong. I left the company and from what I heard, even folks who've been there for close to a decade with IO are trying to get out as well. Unless you're desperate, I wouldn't recommend.

title: poor management
pros: benefits are good and they are strong on safety
cons: Horrible management. Allows certain drivers to not do their jobs with no repercussions, which puts a burden on the other drivers. Low pay. No local human resources so if you have a problem you have to contact a generic human resources email line. It makes reporting issues almost impossible because you have to tell your direct supervisor, which if they are the problem means you can't. The email line only gives generic responses because there is no one who actually knows you and the people you are having issues with.

title: Not a good place to work or grow
pros: You do get paid .
cons: A a records specialist you work in a brutal warehouse environment where the temperature on the 3rd floor gets to over 100 degrees. When I first started I got heat exhaustion and was very sick. My immediate supervisors knew I was sick and did nothing to help me, not even offer me water. You are pushed to your physical limits and management will not care about you health or well being. If you get injured they will blame you and find a way to fire you. Management and supervisors do not intervene when employees are aggressive or hostile and they just expect you to work it out. The company is not very ethical in regards to processes and expect you to tow the line and say yes sir not matter what.

title: Matrixed Conglomerate of M&As Trying to Operate as One Company
pros: Good-enough commitment to the general safety of all employees during the pandemic. Iron Mountain does its best to protect essential employees and have offered remote work flexibility to nonessential employees.
cons: - They're obsessed with M&As; they seem to always be acquiring/merging new business units and selling old ones. - Overkill of meetings and email threads. - Frequent self-serving power plays across different departments and business units. - Lots and lots and LOTS of presentation slides shared with and edited by anyone with an email address. - Everyone's working with and regurgitating large amounts of data, yet few can clearly explain any of it. - And, sadly, there's a bit of corporate posturing that creates an overall forced sense of employee spirit. Everyone's your friend, here, but no one's really your friend, here. This is just an abridged list.

title: You will get over worked and stressed
pros: Great benefits, great pay, you get a yearly bonus, great people to work with.
cons: You will be overworked. If you are salary expect to work over 40 hours a week. Expect to be overwhelmed with work and be working 12-17 hour days and expect to be on call even though you are salary. Expect to work on the weekend. No work life balance at all.

title: With President Brennan out, lots of changes.... some, not so good.
pros: Although the benefits package is good, salaries are lagging with industry comparable companies. Also, the business model is changing, but the company feverishly continues to focus on "a box on the shelf and a tape in the slot." Digital is the future, so its surprising that Mr. Reese decided to forego that path.
cons: Its interesting to see that while the company's core beliefs are espoused constantly, posted in every location, and talked about ad nauseum, they are not really taken to heart.

title: Senior Leadership
pros: Iron Mountain is a large company and if your willing to relocate...then you may be able to advance within the company. There are lot of good people there but most are looking for another opportunity
cons: Upper management is guided by a group of minority shareholders who own a majority position in the company. Its all about the money with these people and they could care less about the hourly workers, In the last two years it has been a constant theme of due more with less (people) and every other month or so their is a RIF (reduction in force) so more work for those that choose to tough it out

title: Solution Representative
pros: Leader in the industry by number of clients and footprint worldwide. It was a great place to work in the late 90 and early 00.
cons: Management has for neglected their customer base and has lower the level of service they provide them and the competition has taken some off their largest clients over the last few years. The incompetent managers instead of being fire are just move around to other divisions. Since they decide to change to a REIT their focus has been increasing revenue at all cost, meaning lowering service while increasing prices.

title: Senior Management Is Failing This Company
pros: Good, dedicated staff for most part
cons: No room for growth. Poor lower level and middle management. Company seems to have no strategic plan "ini actives" seem to be recycled ideas that have laden tried by other companies and doomed to fail, for example digital imaging, the REIT conversation which has made a laughingstock of the company and off shoring to India when trend in industry is to bring jobs back on shore

title: no advancement?
pros: Great co-workers! Benefits are good. Company is strong. Different departments/areas work well with each other in general (There will always be individuals who can be difficult).
cons: Can burn out easily. A lot of restructuring going on and transitioning a major acquisition. I have been full-time at Iron Mountain for close to eight years and the past three have been somewhat chaotic. This is resulting in turnover either by Iron Mountain or people leaving on their own. But for me, the pros outweigh the cons. I have seen what a great company this can be and am staying on to see it come back.

title: Leadership
pros: For the first part of my career the company was a great place to work. The people were great and the company always seemed to take care of its employees by doing the right thing for them.
cons: Within the last 2 years of my employment with the company, everything has changed. 1. Leadership has become very clique. 2. The company is no longer focused on taking care of its employees. 3. Sales reps have become just a number 4. Favortism exists at the leadership level that promotes the wrong message and allows low performers to dictate the success of the Sales team. 5. High performers are expected to pick up the slack of low performers with no added incentive or recognition causing them to burn out. 6. Lack of trust for the Leadership team which causes the sales reps to perform out of fear

title: Good Company
pros: A lot of great benefits including up to 5% match of 401K, 3 weeks vacation to start for salary employees and development opportunities. They encourage you to "own your business" and although there is a lot of structure, you have a lot of freedom to make decisions and run the business your way.
cons: Long hours and your experience is heavily influenced by who you report to directly. They are heavily metric based which can lead to decisions that are not best for the customer, when I left I believe they were trying to move away from metrics a bit (people work towards these numbers to make bonus)

title: One employe's learning experience
pros: The work is fairly fulfilling if you have an analytical or statistical frame of mind. You learn all the many facets of 2D and 3D geophysical data in the Oil and Gas industry. The work isn't all that difficult if you are willing to learn the basics. You manage clients file rooms and corporate libraries.
cons: The work is outsourced to various clients locations. Even though you work full-time, you are usually treated like temp workers by the client. Only supervisors and managers are supposed to interact with the clients full-time employees. The lower echelons are supposed to keep their heads down and become invisible to the client company.

title: Product Support Specialist
pros: Benefits were decent and the quarterly bonuses were nice.
cons: People were promoted because of who they know and not based on actual knowledge of the company. It’s not good when a supervisor comes into a role with zero knowledge of the team and what they do. What’s worse is a year later they still have no idea. Upper management does not care about the people who actually work with the customers on a daily basis and make horrible company decisions without doing any research. People are over worked and extremely under paid. It is really easy to get stuck.

title: Over-worked and under-paid
pros: There were some good days, but it all depends on your team. If they are reliable, it's a relatively good job,
cons: I was told I should be there every day when the first driver comes in for his route in the morning and when the last one comes back in the evening. This would mean 14 hour days every day of the work week. There is no reason behind this and when I pointed that out the manager simply said, "They need to see you when they come in and when they leave". Leaving for some time in the middle of the day to balance that was also deemed unacceptable.

title: Misleading
pros: Always hiring - but wouldn't recommend this company to a criminal on work release.
cons: Paid less that the work we do, poor training to complete the required work, micromanagement to the fullest. The only thing missing is informing supervisor how much I went to the bathroom. Management talks "at you" not "to you. when hired was guarenteed a bonus of 12%. Haven't seen one greater than 2% in 2 years. Promotions go to the wrong people for the positions. Major favortism/politics.

title: Director
pros: What I Love about my role at Iron Mountain is that it is challenging, allows me to use my skills to impact my team and our customers. I know what I do and what my team does matters to the organization and the customers who trust us with their important assets. I work with a great group of individuals who are always willing to help out, answer any question and they do it with a smile. We have great benefits, and a good work-life balance.
cons: We are a growing company, and that means we aren't stagnant, and are changing and making improvements. You have to move to move up, we are on the move.

title: Everything Changes
pros: Iron Mountain is, hands down, the best at what they do in the records and information management and data protection industry. I still highly recommend Iron Mountain to many businesses that I deal with. During the time I worked at Iron Mountain, I interacted daily with some of the most intelligent and talented people that I've ever had the privilege of working with, at every level of the company. Great pay and excellent benefits on top of that. I worked for Iron Mountain for eight years, and for many years, it was great. I loved my job, made great money. Until my last 2 years, I had worked with wonderful managers who were mature, professional business people; Managers who treated their people with respect and dignity, which made me want to do a great job in return. At a corporate level, there were always resources available, ready and willing to help. I was proud to be a part of this world-class organization. It was a wonderful ride, until it wasn't...
cons: Enter a shift in management, beginning at the local operations level, then at the sales level. Allow a district to be run by immature, incompetent managers who had one agenda,their own, and you have the ingredients for the perfect storm of disaster. When I first started at Iron Mountain, it was an honor to work side-by-side with mature professionals who were clearly focused on bottom line revenue, who had no use for money and time-wasting feel-good efforts such as party planning and office redecorating. Towards the end of my tenure however, this is what the focus became at the local level, rather than the focus being on running a best-in-class service-delivery organization. How this was tolerated at the Executive level is a mystery. The hourly employees wanted a yearly bonus, not a party. The annual company picnics had been working just fine. My colleagues and I were very successful at our jobs for many years. As I mentioned, we had great sales managers who supported us 100%, respected us, and treated us as adults, as professionals. We were not used to managers who believed that bullying and intimidation tactics were acceptable behaviors, and the ways to achieve results. We went from a professional business environment to feeling as if we had time warped back to grade school. Furthermore, the overall structure of the sales force changed dramatically over the years, and not necessarily for the better. As the company grew and attempted to expand from a paper environment into the digital realm, the sales force became ridiculously large, with layer upon layer of sales reps, and account managers for various vertical markets and large accounts. A sale that used to be closed by one rep, now required an entire army. “Teaming to Win,” was the name of the new game. Everybody was now supposed to be a part of the sales process, and the end results were, very often, completely counter-productive, leaving the customer not knowing who their main contact actually was. Given this type of structure, it is no surprise, that within the last 3 years, the sales force has had 2 massive layoffs. Ultimately, Iron Mountain Digital was sold due to lack-luster performance, which can be directly attributed to lack of vision and direction at the Executive level. What’s my advice to anyone seeking employment at Iron Mountain? I still think it is a great company, just be aware that there’s the good, and the bad, and know that every district is not created equal. Change is the only constant at this company. Also, be very aware of increasing competition, specifically, from in-house scanning operations and very robust enterprise content management (ECM) programs that can also serve as very good records management platforms. Shredding is still viewed a commodity, and always will be, and there are a lot of other companies doing a great job at data backup and data protection.

title: The Mountain... The Mountain... what will become of the Mountain?
pros: Many utterly fabulous truly caring employees at the customer interaction levels. Corporate soul (if such a thing exists) is honorable & generous.
cons: It was astonishing in a sales setting to have not one manager who had experienced any aspect of the job for which they were actively managing employees... To have new employees not able to ask their managers how to do their jobs (because they hadn't a clue) was quite completely insane. When I was there I was in on the founding of 3 departments (all successful)... We had to invent the job, do the job & then train new employees (as mentors) because the metrics driven management didn't include actual knowledge of the job as an ingredient! Yikes...A larger part of the job comprised increasing spend from larger accounts. This was hindered by the gargantuan task of making the Mountain appear as a professional seamless organization to its customers. The is to say it took much energies to make the absolute definition of dysfunction appear to be something that it wasn't. Nevertheless we were successful. This was mitigated by the fact that 150 companies were formed into one & unifying culture is not easy...Initially the atmosphere/culture was congenial almost collegial. In the early days Iron Mountain prided itself on never having had a mass layoff.. With the retirement of the much beloved CEO/Founder there was the expected shift. The new CEO came from the Airline Industry & appeared to lack the charismatic character of his predecessor. In fact initially he seemed to be sort of a cold fish. Outsourcing contracts to India (with much bounceback & lack of understanding from same) has hopefully been mitigated. The few remaining US contract reps had to do all the work because the Indians were clueless. Outsourcing customer service to the Phillipines initlally irritated customers... Moral has crashed. A wonderful culture has been gutted... Mass annual layoffs are now the norm... I realized that from 30,000 feet this is all meaningless. The core business of IM is not really the business of Iron Mountain (as is the case in many business)... The real business is the money borrowing business. The business is to statistically massage the numbers to appear as pristine to wall street as possible by MBA driven numerical gymnastics.This facilitates the lines of credit necessary to keep the whole ball of wax moving... Part of these metrics includes finding earnings by massive layoffs... Hence the new culture has arrived... A competitor said in a recent job interview that Iron Mountain is now just a "stock play"...

title: Territory Vice President
pros: Dynamic organization, with plenty of potential. Very strong brand name and a company with high integrity. You will work hard, but the compensation plan is fair and can be rewarding if you successfully hit your goals.
cons: Senior leadership could be more strategic with their long term planning, and more inclusive of field leaderships input. the latest mantra is "it's your business to run", but quite honestly, that hasn't been the case for several years. They have become to metric driven, at the expense of customer service and front line employee moral.

title: Sales support and enablement - Data Center
pros: The old adage that employees are attracted to companies because they are well known - that is no longer true - people might be want to work for that company, but now they leave the company due to the people; environment or culture. Not at Iron Mountain, they have people and tools ready to make the new hire welcomed and glad to be a part of the company. Fantastic culture, and excellent environment. It is ALL inclusive and the leaders constantly and consistently keep the staff apprised of the latest and greatest. One happy employee - going on 5 months and still smiling and grateful!
cons: Their IT department needs some process improvement - and a better succession plan.

title: Good Work-life balance with uncertainty
pros: There was a good deal of Flexibility and good work-life balance at the locations I worked at. I had a good team and enjoyed the core group of people I worked with for a long time. Company continues to acquire.
cons: For employees Iron Mountain is synonymous with Uncertainty, Constant change of direction, and numerous reorganization. People now are always speculating about the next round of cuts and there is continual uneasiness. It's not the company it used to be.

title: Transportation Supervisor
pros: Drivers were good/hard working guys. Plant workers were a lively bunch, kept the environment fun. Pay and benefits were good
cons: No structural training program, they have what's call a sentinel training program but they just disregard it and throw you in and good luck. The drivers only get about a week's worth of training. I was a PM Supervisor and there was no inclusion on projects taking place during the day. Numerous times I would come in and my peers will be working on projects that I had no idea of or what was going on. Management was not around, my manager was 400 miles away and most communication was just through email or phone.

title: GREED disguised as a "GLOBAL BUSINESS RE-ALIGNMENT"
pros: Self-motivated, respectful, intelligent, conscientious team mates.
cons: Current top executives under-estimate the intelligence of their employees & their customers. Outsourcing work to the Philippines (legally still in the "USA") was another knee-jerk business decision to simply quickly sweeten the asset bottom line. However, once customers are enlightened to where their support is, Iron Mountain will be right back where they started with searching for the next business tactic to improve profit margins or even remain solvent. This recent business tactic will have such a negative financial ripple affect that even the executives may have to golf at a public golf course instead of their country clubs.

title: Transportation Supervisor
pros: Major players in the business. Always growing and buying existing competitors. If you work hard and do it the IM way.... You can go and be anything you desire. I met Bill Meaney, CEO. Super nice guy who cares.......yes, cares...
cons: Noting really.... The pay comes, but i would try to get the highest salary if you are non -exempt because ht e2.5-3% tops raises are pretty weak.

title: Culture
pros: Good business model, with strong upside potential. Starting to see some focus on changing the culture, by bringing in new executive leaders external to the company.
cons: Depending on location, culture can be challenging for new employees who are not openly accepted by the highly tenured employees. Too many executives there for over 30 years starting out as drivers and other administrative roles, with no external company or industry experience, not allowing for acceptance of new ways of doing things. New leader ideas were often challenged and not accepted, causing issues with credibility from the tenured staff, who would default to the tenured executive leaders perspective. If they can continue to bring in fresh perspectives and eliminate the perception of a "Good Old Boys" network, they can should be able to continue being a premier leader in this industry.

title: Company is going though change, but good - necessary change.
pros: Heavy focus on developing people and skills. Good salaries and benefits. Leadership cares a lot about the people of the company. The company is going through major structural and leadership change right now. It will be a little while before these changes take effect -- so my opinion is neutral for now, but I think the changes were necessary.I believe and hope the they will bring on positive effects.
cons: There has been a lack of vision since the sale of the digital business. If the company isn't the one to bridge physical and digital records management, what is the future? Paper storage is profitable, but for how long will the business be relevant?

title: Outsourced Records Specialist
pros: Health insurance is decent. Manager allows you to watch tv, video and sleep at your desk while contracting for major corporate clients. Hard-working people are punished for calling out other people's laziness.
cons: Greater restrictions on vacation time accrual imposed. Very low salary increases. Unqualified and uneducated managment. Lousy treatment of low-level employees under lazy, passive-aggressive managment.

title: Uncertainty and upheaval
pros: Fair-to-above market compensation, depending on where you live. Good benefits. Some exceptional people on staff.
cons: Industry is rapidly changing, and the company is behind the curve. Every year brings sweeping change in team structure, territory, account lists and compensation structure making it difficult to stay on top of things. Lots of layoffs have lowered morale and career expectations. Very difficult to move up the ladder unless you're willing to relocate. Little diversity above the front lines. While there are some sharp folks employed here, there are also some very dull folks - promotions don't always seem to go to the most deserving.

title: It was a great company during its growth stage in the 90s & 00s
pros: The people, teams, and synergies created, cultivated, and helped drive the mission, vision, and values at Iron Mountain. A very impressive service organization that worked very hard at creating consistent operations in North America. Impressive CEO and leadership team.
cons: The Digital acquisition(s) were not in the best interest of Iron Mountain. I was not surprised that institutional investors pressured IM to deliver better returns or divest. The wrong successors were picked for some senior management transitions, but they seem to have a good team in place now.

title: Great, changing company
pros: I've worked with Iron Mountain for 10+ years. As the industry has changed, so has the company. After becoming a REIT and acquiring Recall, our growth strategy in both developed and emerging business is strong. Leadership values talent and invests in development. Many efforts underway to strengthen the culture and value innovation and inclusion.
cons: As with any large, global organization, change is a constant. If you aren't flexible and resilient, Iron Mountain likely isn't the environment for you. Company needs an internal social media platform to better collaborate with colleagues around the world.

title: Be careful taking Sales Role
pros: Nice people to work with
cons: The worst on-boarding experience. For sales reps you don't have a laptop or any of the hundreds of passwords needed to do your job. Also, if you like your quota doubled or tripled just because an outside research company said that you only have a small share of the market then this role is for you. IM employs so many sales trainers and the training is not valid (unless you want to watch over 50 videos). The storage business is slowing down and it's all about technology and paperless work flows now. IM is still trying to figure out who they are on the electronic front. Buyer beware here.

title: Data Entry Specialist/Other Stuff
pros: I am sorry for those of you who work at IM's that are not as great as mine, but we are consistently in the top 10 of metrics, our management and people are wonderful, and my job changes on a daily basis, so it is never rote. We are a very cohesive team. I adore working here, and (hopefully) will be for a very, very long time. I am very proud to be a Mountaineer!
cons: Dusty, old buildings. Probably have gone through 1,000,000 sheets of Kleenex by now...

title: Good and Bad
pros: Great people. Everyone on the front lines works together to be successful and assist our customers. Good benefits Great tools and thought process around coaching and learning structure
cons: Poor long term senior leadership vision Too tough to sell in an operation first driven environment Change structure and programs all the time - don’t allow things to succeed or fail No upward mobility for career pathing

title: Destruction Coordinator
pros: None after my experiences
cons: Supervisor and plant manager had me go through training on the computer for 2 and a half to 3 weeks. After which, I was thrown on the floor and never formally trained on how to do anything. The only reason why I learned anything is because I asked questions. 5 weeks after I was on the floor, I was terminated....no warning...no write ups....no guidance. I was just sent out on a limb and it was sawn off behind me. If this is the new wave of hiring and firing, I want no part. Don't waste your time. Nobody has time to gamble with their income. Bills don't stop just because some crappy job decides you're "not the best person" for the job two months after they hire. It was a waste of their time and money. And...God knows it was a waste of my time and talents!

title: STAY AWAY from SALES and the COMPANY!
pros: - ONLY PRO work from home twice a week. Which creates work balance and applies to only the business executives! Unfair right ?
cons: Where do I begin with this horrible department! - Poor management - Poor training - Unprofessionally and immature management - Manager is NEVER NEVER available and expects you to hit your numbers and quota - unattainable metrics and quota - more like inside sales call center - gain no experience or knowledge in this horrible department - management love to blame and point the finger to the employees for their mistakes - uncomfortable work environment and management loves to talk about the employees behind their back. - if you want a headache and just go completely insane work in this horrible department

title: Collegeville PA DM is Not Stable, Fair Warning
pros: Benefits are good, the remote sales executives were great to work, most the team has been laid of so they are trying to rebuild the organization with all key players missing. They stoped selling cloud which is where this business is heading.
cons: No Job Security what so ever, I worked with guys that were way over 100 percent quota and had great pipelines and one day they had massive lay offs with no explanation. The management is very hands off, and almost non existent unless lay offs or other majors road block appears.

title: Mortgage Solutions
pros: Lots of bonuses, lots of hours and plenty of work! Pretty decent benefit package, affordable and very fair. Company training in every area. Cross training usually available. International corporation. With room for advancement. Promote from within many of the positions. Several people have long tenure/worked there a long time or transferred upon merge having many years of employment with company that merged.
cons: Pay rate is very low. Favoritism is predominant. Mandatory o/t. Some management issues with some specific managers. Some departments are more layed back then others..

title: Beat around the bush
pros: Great co-workers. Great co-workers! Great co-workers!
cons: Over 200+ people have either been laid off or will find out their status tomorrow as to a job. They beat around the bush on everything and especially in today's meeting. Outsourcing a majority of our hard work to the Philippines. Don't tell you anything direct. It's more read between the lines. Don't ask questions or it will come back to bite you someway somehow.

title: OK company to work for, but clearly has lost some of its luster
pros: With a right attitude and a strong desire to want to do more, this organization will respond by providing excellent opportunities. I started in collections and worked my way to one of the company's top billing analysts, but only after I had applied myself by going back to school for my graduate degree and asking for more work to do. I was a trusted and valued employee there for a number of years as a result, and felt a part of a large "family", wanting to serve and support the customer base at a high level. The company culture has been better and has been communicated well by HR; it has definitely changed from when I first started with the company over 10 years ago.
cons: The organization is undergoing a large transition by shipping most of its transactional data and work overseas as part of a cost cutting measure, although senior leadership will not communicate that to its current employees for fear of political reasons. There is not a great deal of immediate future opportunities for advancement, as there have been 3 job cuts in the last 5 years (2009-2013). The transactional data transition has not been as smooth as the senior leadership believes it has been (in fact, it's been quite rocky and very inconsistent), and the amount of customer anger is building. Issues where customers are receiving refund checks and past due statements from the organization at the same time are becoming common. In my job as a billing specialist, there were 7 different middle managers and/or VPs between myself and the CEO of the company. One VP stated in an all-employee quarterly meeting that Iron Mountain was "behind the times" when it came to job cutbacks; to me, this was a direct slap in the face to those workers that have been faithful to the organization and provided no peace to people's job security.

title: Solution Development Executive
pros: Great managers that look out for you and help you grow. They believe in a balanced life style yet work hard. Great teamwork with little politics (huge company so they are there). They invest in their sales reps and training along with tools to help them be successful. The local Territory VPs are great to partner with to make sure deals are successful and profitable.
cons: Moves a bit slow to make changes due to the size of the company Lots of change with territories and reps

title: Sales
pros: Commission, good people in the ranks
cons: HR is the worst at this company, especially at the Limerick location. A friend of mine was a victim of sexual harrassment at this company, and after going to HR, they pretty much just said, that they were aware of the issues with the employee they reported, and did absolutely NOTHING. Furthermore, management only cares about what is best for them, and if you have an issue; similar to the stellar HR dept. (sarcasm) they will do nothing. If you are already stuck with this organization I wish you the best, but if not I would steer clear

title: Run Away Worked in WI.
pros: Persons on teams, back in the days when employees were valued I would say it was a good place to work.
