cons: Always in state of change, acquire other companys putting their team members in place. Then fire / layoff or drive off solid employees that in turns does not work out and all of their new choice employees they put in place are released due to poor work performance. Have seen this take place over and over with out anyone leaning from the past.

title: Company is good to work for, but not locally.
pros: Good benefits. Fair pay for position. Employees work hard and most have good company spirit in face to face with customers.
cons: Local management out of touch with ground level employees. Too many corporate initiatives too fast leaves many employees lost and has the effect of not getting proper buy in at employee level. Most employees fear getting fired for making ANY mistake. Not a healthy environment.

title: Great Place
pros: culture, cafeteria, very friendly environment. they are a big company with a lot of resources so training and getting you up to speed is offered.
cons: while I was there I was in the top 5 consistently in brining in new business. I also contributed greatly to mentoring new hires and wherever else I could. Point being is that they just cared if you brought in your #. If you hit it they left you alone, if you didn't hit it you were on the way out the door. there was no real encouragement to look at us to promote from within.

title: Your experience depends on your manager
pros: Solid reputation Brand is synonymous with quality
cons: Difficult to understand comp plan Seems slanted to favor men

title: outsourcing of jobs to India, limited tech promotional opportunities, frustration over sales growth compared to competi
pros: team of competent and highly skilled engineers ok benefits relativey stable thanks to physical archival business
cons: Below market pay for most engineers Inability to rapidly grow various digital services when compared with competitors

title: Great People - But needs a strategic vision for future growth
pros: - The People/Culture. Iron Mountain employees are bright, hard working, and cooperative. They want to do the best job possible regardless of which department you deal with. The people are by far the best thing about the company. - Benefits and Pay - Fair. They are pretty fair and standard for a large enterprise organization. - Layoffs - Company had two big layoffs in two years. However, the last layoff, they treated most people with dignity and respect. Gave a good severance, gave people a transition time before they had to leave, Communication was open and up front about the changes. I think the senior leadership team really treated and handled the people better the most companies I've heard about. - Name Recognition - It's the most well known name in the document storage business. It also has a global presence and no competitors that have anywhere near the same national footprint.
cons: - Lack of strategic vision for the future. Sales people are still asked to focus on selling paper document storage - something that is quickly becoming obsolete. Commissions on other services like scanning are quite low and pricing is not competitive. Company has focused too much on short term gain of selling paper storage revenue, but how long is that going to last? - Converted to a REIT to save on taxes - but unclear how becoming a real estate investment trust for tax breaks shows the company is looking towards to future growth and innovation in the US market.

title: Great Company To Work For
pros: Great management support and personal development. My managers give me the support and guidance needed to do a good job and improve my skills.
cons: Being a large company we can move a little slow sometimes, but this has been improving. In order to function at the scale we do it's necessary to have a lot of structure and procedures. These are great for keeping everything running though it takes some getting used to. Considering that we're dealing with the worlds most important records and artifacts, all that oversight makes sense.

title: Becoming Mediocre
pros: Dominant company in core records management business. Equity compensation pays good dividends. Good health plan, but poor 401(k) match for higher compensated. Had a strong culture and sense of pride. Ability to work remotely and from home
cons: Becoming a REIT has been so mixed, mostly bad. The company has been on a cost cutting tear since the summer of 2015, and leadership doesn't seem to have a plan to end it. The latest efforts make little to no sense. Good people keep leaving and are replaced by mediocre people because that's all they can get, or they are ex-EMC employees that needed a job. They have not bought into the company or it's culture. On my fourth manager in less than 2 years. They want to play in the data center business, but now they are going up against the big boys (Google, Amazon, Microsoft, Oracle, etc.). Their trying to buy their way into this business, and probably overpaid for Fortrust and IO. Exempt employees have been bearing most of the burden. Our budgets are arbitrarily cut, but the workload keeps increasing. Team morale continues to decline. Meanwhile, they outsourced and offshored Finance, IT and HR back office functions, and getting anything done now takes more time than it used to. Worst of all, at least personally, they have cut back our vacation twice and are about to do it a third time. Many people kept time on the books for the possible layoff, which they continue to do, but can't hedge that anymore.

title: This is a very manually hard job
pros: Ther are a few, I think that this is a great steady job. There isnt a lot of turn over in the transportation area, because most of the guys are lifers. The ins. is great as well
cons: Most days you're going to be out untill at least 6pm if not later than that, it all depends on how many guys call in sick. For those of us who dont than our work load is gruling at times. Advanement is not easy, especially if you want a position that requires you have a degree.

title: Steady Job
pros: It's a pretty big company with decent benefits. Retirement and Employee Stock Purchase Plan, medical, vacation ect. You have the opportunity to transfer and pretty much go wherever you want in the US.
cons: Thanks pay per hour should be better. The Shred Division has lots of OT available but that's because Iron Mountain always runs with a skeleton crew. So it's possible to make some extra money but your body and home life will pay for it.

title: Killed the commissions - lost their best people
pros: Solid company with a good revenue base and recurring revenue streams. The people in the front line sales group are great to work with, but upper management leaves much to be desired.
cons: As a sales person with a compensation plan that is 50:50 base to commission it can be lucrative. When management reassigns the entire book of business for most people and pays the most commission for selling storage, they're setting sales executives up for failure. Most big businesses are using Iron Mountain for storage, they are the best in the business. The trouble is, when a sales executive's book of business is nearly 100% vended with Iron Mountain and the total outstanding opportunity doesn't add up to the quota, there's no chance of hitting the number and making money. There's also a long sales cycle so a brand new book of business is not going to provide returns for many months. There are many reps making zero commission and have been making zero commissions for months. Many of the top people that aren't interested in earning a base salary alone have left. I'm not sure why some good people still remain. I guess they're hopeful for change and waiting to see what 2014 brings. Reps need to sell imaging and document management solutions but execution once deals are signed is poor. They tend to lose the customer before they fix all of the issues and get it ramped up. It's not a place for strong sales executives wanting to make a great income. The existing client base can be maintained with account managers but not sales people.

title: Iron Mountain
pros: I have been with Iron Mountain for 21 years, and I have been allotted numerous opportunities and growth throughout those years. I have been able to attend many learning and development classes, travel for growth, and get my Six Sigma Yellow Belt. Iron Mountain invests in its employees, their growth, and their development.
cons: Changes in the organization. It is something that happens with a lot of companies, and understandable why it happens. Over the years, I have seen so much change, some of it was warranted, and others made me question the company's direction. However, any change Iron Mountain went through, in time, the reasons became clearer. Sticking with Iron Mountain through all of it has made me the employee I am today.

title: Ever changing
pros: Great co-workers. Lots of opportunities (non-manager) to be a part of the changes that will make Iron Mountain the international company (Bill Meaney and BOD) is designing. Very modern approach to new technology.
cons: Iron Mountain is professionally recognized for its fast past company restructure(s) and new technology(ies) rolled out. Rollouts have not allow time and resources for accuracy audit, corrective enhancements and knowledge dissemination. VP, Manager and field employees are without knowledge or support as they navigate these changes. And NO, a “How to” is not adequate support in the field. Iron Mountain (and investors) is still betting on its REIT conversion, regardless the US company continues to move its structure and resources internationally.

title: Ups and Downs
pros: Financial stability, known brand, excellent benefits, fair compensation. The company is relatively stable and sizable enough to deliver both decent compensation and plenty of lateral and vertical opportunity.
cons: With a shifting market place, the company has spent YEARS trying to figure out who it wants to be. The legacy (lion share) of company revenue is stable at best. Leadership has been slow to respond to the market and employees lack confidence in what tomorrow may bring.

title: The fall from the Mountain is steep.
pros: Started off very much enamored with the culture, the commitment and the people. Own a tremendous amount of market share globally. Any competition is bought up.
cons: Culture has been lost. Leadership changes every 6 months. No confidence in where the company is going, who is in charge and who is making decisions. Unless you are in sales, you really don't matter. It's all about the quarterly numbers and the street.

title: Pretty good place
pros: Fairly stable due to recurring base of revenue, good people, good benefits, regular but small raises, promotion opportunities are available, solid training for many roles,
cons: Layoffs following Recall acquisition, industry is dying, lack of direction from management about future, moving from offices to cubes for director and below even where real estate is cheap, outsourcing lots of functions, very siloed, confusion over ownership of certain areas

title: Sales Management
pros: The attraction to Iron Mountain lies within its fair pay, great benefits and strong footprint within the industry. The environment is fast paced and always changing. Many thrive in this environment, others may find it a challenge and distraction. You will learn a lot about technology, business and the many other aspects of B2B sales if this is a new endeavor for you. You literally will own your business and strategy. This is a great company where you will learn and be surrounded with a caring and collaborative environment. A great place for people new to sales looking to learn and grow professionaly from this experience.
cons: The organization is plagued with leaders that have endured due to politics vs success or true ability to lead. Most often, decisons are based on personal relationships vs business needs. Though the competitive landscape and industry are changing, Iron Mountain still continues to go after paper storage. No matter what you are hired to do, it's important to note that paper storage will be your key objective despite the fact that the company has so much more to offer from a technological/services standpoint. Make sure to ask about this when interviewing so that you are clear about what it is you will pressured to sell and grow. Paper storage, no matter the customer base, is mostly a price driven sell. You may be brought in under the impression that there is so much to sell along with many resources....this could be the case, but the reality is, paper storage is king at Iron Mountain and is what you will be responsible to grow. Make sure you understand this before leaving another company. Ask many questions and specifically ask about comp and what the average successful sales person made in 2014 & 2015 in commissions. Not a healthy environment for experienced sales people.

title: Could be worse
pros: The biggest pro to my job was my team. I got along well with almost all of my colleagues and my immediate manager was a great boss.
cons: Upper management seems to have the company in a cost cutting mode. Over the years I was there, I saw customer facing teams get dismantled and outsourced over seas. This severely impacted customer service to the point where about half of the new customers we set up ended up being dissatisfied.

title: Working the warehouses
pros: Good crew. Organized and up to date equipment.
cons: Dusty inventory product. Some things are difficult to lift. Narrow work aisles. Time for daily work processing is stressful and time pressed. Not all coordinators follow company policies. HR is a joke, your problem never leaves local management. Discriminatory remarks made about older workers during meetings. Favoritism and non-disciplinary action noted for selected individuals. Annual raise is standard 50 cents per hour, not worth what you put in.

title: Good for a few months but be prepared
pros: Early shifts Decent parking, depending on the facility The work itself
cons: This is the first company I’ve ever worked for that encourages employees to talk ABOUT each other instead of TO each other. If they don’t “personally” like you, although you are a good hard working employee, they will let you go and say your “contract” has been terminated. Those overseeing work being done are gossipy and stand around talking about employees that are in the same room. There is also a lot of nepotism and I feel that plays a part in someone getting hired permanent. Pretty unfair practices all around. There is a lot of favoritism and they aren’t shy about it, unfortunately.

title: Too Big Too Change
pros: IM des business with ()% of Fortune 500 companies. Their customers are great and a pleasure to work with. Top Corporate Leadership communicates effectively and seems to know about the local level challenges.
cons: Top Leadership understands the challenges but can't seem to alleviate them for the local offices. There are so many obstacles to success it is hard to stay focused on the goal. Customers have very bad experiences. High turnover. Local Management lacks leadership. Local offices are corrupt, harbor bullies and negativity, and steal your soul as you walk through the door.

title: TImes change, and not always for the best
pros: Good benefits that are partially employer paid Competitive salary
cons: Lack of transparency from upper management to frontline employees Little flexibility for working remotely for positions that can be done without being in the same building as the team Fewer mid-level positions in North America due to moving entire departments to other countries, leaving no growth opportunity Reducing work staff AND hours, but expecting the same level of output in less time with less people

title: Typical Work Place
pros: The pay is alright and the supervisors and coordinators are easy to get along with. The benefits are also fairly good. Incentive compensation is offered quarterly so that is always a nice bonus. Promotes from within.
cons: Everything continuously changes and it's since it's corporation everything comes down to the bottom line for all the share holders. The company policies themselves make the job suck at times. Like most places upper management has no clue what people actually goes through on a daily basis.

title: Horrible!
pros: Remote work environment for everyone.
cons: Everything. The managers and upper management are completely disconnected. I had HR involved and they were absolutely terrible. The HR woman looked at me in my face and when I asked ‘don’t you care, don’t you feel bad even a little’ to which she replied, ‘No.’ I quit and now am determined to never get myself in another situation like Iton Mountain. Classic corporate environment where managers are promoted not based on whether they will be good managers, but due to circumstances and seniority. If you want a corporate job and to be treated like nothing but a ‘employee at will’ and you should just be happy you have a job and are getting paid money - then work for Iron Mountain. If you want to be respected for your work, I suggest you go elsewhere- for your own sanity and safety.

title: Almost 20 years for a reason
pros: IM has always been an inclusive and overall great place to work. I enjoy having ideas actually heard. My direct manager has always been very positive and approachable. Same goes for his direct manager. In my region it has always been a trickle down from the top. We stay positive and do the right thing, for the good of the customer... without them we wouldn't be here.
cons: Technology is lacking in some areas and as a global leader in our field we should have nothing but the best.

title: Weak Plan Poor Execution
pros: Workforce is dedicated to a fault. Good people who genuinely care
cons: Management is weak from the top down Manages from the director level down are poorly trained and for the most part ineffective. Major initiatives are poorly executed resulting in dual work, inefficient processes and chaos when attempting to meet deadlines.

pros: Really I think the best reason to work at Iron Mountain is for the benefits. They were outstanding! Co workers were ok. Some great, some not so great.
cons: Management makes changes on a whim, without even consulting the employees that actually do the job and have been there well over a decade. The pay is terrible, you practically have to beg to work over time just to make ends meet. The raises are horrible, you can have a fantastic review, and your "raise" would be 30 cents.

title: Hugely Disappointing
pros: Never worried about a paycheck. Nice facility. Half decent equipment. Spent boat loads of money on labs
cons: Iron Mountain is not a software company. Even with software execs at the top, they could not develop what customers wanted, market what we had, or sell it. They could not even penetrate their own sales and marketing org. Comp package was based largely on factors employees could not control. Most were/are underpaid. Medical plans not that good and very expensive. Bizarre promotions internally, many with no relative experience promoted to mid mgmt positions.

title: Good company to work for but be prepared to be a small fish in a big pond.
pros: Two weeks vacation to start, medical benefits are reasonable affordable, able to buy discounted stock options, good pay, good people below General Management.
cons: Too caught up in being non-union, too caught up in metrics instead of being customer-focused, stock price has not changed so to make it move new CEO laid off over 800 people in 2013-stock still hasn't moved.

pros: Loved my coworkers, always there to help each other. Not all managers or supervisors I have heard great things about, but I was really lucky with my team. Flex time available to most is great.
cons: Globalization is happening more and more, letting go of a lot of good people to do this. Even the people staying do not feel stable.

title: Co-Workers Awesome, Iron Mountain Sucks
pros: Your co-workers are usually pretty cool if they are not in any authority type position. The benefits are okay and the pay is decent.
cons: Management is horrible at every level in transportation shred supervisor up. Management is nice to your face, but do not care about you in reality. You are the grunt they will tell you to violate company policy, but the minute an issue arises you get thrown under the bus. Every transportation department needs to unionize like Chicago to save theirselves from being railroaded.

title: Company always in reorganization mode - stay away from support role.
pros: Well maintained facilities and vehicles, annual uniform allowance, competitive pay and bonus. Work life balance is best in the business. Overall, IRM is a professional organization and I would still be working there if I had the choice granted if my cons list didn't exist.
cons: Always in reorganization mode, worried every year that it will be your turn to be let go especially if you are in a support role. No loyalty to long term employees and no real job security. Only those who are fake and part of the club will be considered for promotions. Positions are created for specific individuals behind the scenes so if you arent part of the click you dont really stand a chance at getting a promotion. Also, the company certainly doesn't like vocal employees and doesn't value quality, only productivity at the hourly level. Knowledge and work ethic don't really matter as it ultimately comes down to how much you earn and/or who you know.

title: Challenging & Fulfilling - It is what you make it!
pros: The company has grown and matured over the 20+ years I have been here. Equality, diversity, I am heard and my voice has value is only one of the areas. Iron Mountain will provide you the resources, mentoring, and path for advancement when you put in the work to better yourself and grow professionally and personally. I love a challenge and Iron Mountain keeps me on my toes!
cons: Not really a "con", but you have to stay engaged to remain relevant in the changing work environment of today's market. As the needs of the marketplace change, so must the employee's change. You control your own destiny.

title: Employees are lowest priority
pros: Decent benefits, many supervisors and managers who want their employees to be successful.
cons: The voice of the employee is **completely ignored**. Having been with IRM for 6+ years, and having implemented several programs across the organization that were intended to make jobs easier to accomplish. Company continues to fail when it comes to actually understanding a day in the life of an employee. Senior management make decisions about processes and systems they know absolutely nothing about, when it comes to the employee groups who actually have to live with them on a daily basis. Additionally, the company continues to outsource wherever they can, in order to make more money. I know full-well that in the next 1-2 years, my position will be outsourced, most likely to India. I understand that "business is business", but this company asks SO. MUCH. of their employees in terms of flexibility and acceptance of continually changing direction and priorities. Most employees take these changes in stride, all the while trying to maintain a sense of loyalty. In return, many of these employees are treated so poorly and disposably - not a second thought is given when it's time to reduce staff. There is definitely a "happy medium" that could exist; there are ways to save money and reduce costs without cutting the jobs of extremely loyal employees.

title: Pathetic
pros: Sure can't think of any pros other than the people I worked directly with were great people. Sr management and up in my opinion was useless.
cons: Poor leadership, cutting every corner possible to save a dollar for the shareholders, not telling their employees whats really going on (we're making our own assumptions, believe me). If you are not sr. management, they won't listen to you. You are just a number. Ethics are slipping. Outsourcing jobs overseas. Poor communication to our customers about the changes and assuming they will just be OK with it. Laying off people without ANY consideration of training needed for those who now have to take on those tasks, aside from the fact that you just layed off key people who fully supported your business.

title: Wish it ended differently
pros: The employees that work there are all very friendly and easy to get along with. They are all very driven and passionate about their jobs.
cons: Constant change, which is fine if you are flexible but if you are not beware. The leadership has some high points and some low points and for me the low points just dominate any of the positives.

title: A good traditional company with opportunities for the ambitious, flexible, patient, mobile, and ops-inclined
pros: Work/Life Balance is absolutely attainable if you use your time and focus effectively. Career advancement opportunities are yours for the taking if you actively pursue development and growth opportunities (you must have smart initiative), if you are willing to wait, and if you are willing to relocate. Benefits are solid - middle of the pack for good large companies, and they make continual improvements. Many resources have been expended and made available to all people leaders to help them be better managers for their direct reports. Iron Mountain is always looking to improve. I think the most recent changes have been in everyone's favor and the growth we need might finally take hold.
cons: I haven't worked for many other large corporations, and I hear this is par for most of them, but the reorganization addiction really needs to settle down a bit. This is especially true in the IT department. The disconnect between the aspirational core values and the realities of management/shareholder-driven business decisions is jarring and could use some soul-searching and reconciliation. The supervisor role is in need of a re-evaluation of duties; too much of the role is administrative and tactical, and they need much more time available to spend being mentored and developing their people leadership.

title: Would not recommend
pros: Good insurance, retail discounts, regular reviews, tuition reimbursement, decent pay, reasonable hours for most part. Training opportunities sometimes exist to learn other functions.
cons: Difficult or impossible to meet production targets lead to inaccurate and misplaced inventory. Local management is very reactionary, short sighted, and doesn't have a grasp on what is required to run the operations accurately and productively. Warehouses are dirty and in poor condition, as is the inventory. It's very hard to attract and retain staff. Approvals for staffing are based on past volumes completed, not current and future projected volumes.

title: Diverse days; low pay
pros: Diverse days, independent, very limited micromanagement; Trust you're competent.
cons: low pay to start, no growth, very small pay increase per year (roughly 30 cents....barely keeps up with inflation).

title: Choosing to leave
pros: There are generally some good people at this company, with good intentions. However they are often not the people in a place of power, and if they do they don't leverage their position to make a positive difference.
cons: I have found many of my co-workers petty, dishonest, and not team players. Decisions are told in a manner which does not consider peoples feelings. I heard of someone who was in NYC and fired over the phone during Hurricane Sandy so that IRM would not have to let people go in November - too close to the holiday. I hate to say it, but here the squeaky wheel gets the grease, and those with bad attitudes have more say than the positive people.

title: What a disappointment for such a large organization.....
pros: They had really great benefits to include legal help. There was some flexibility in work schedule. I liked that they were diverse in their business model.
cons: The entire organization was a mess. It didn't seem like anyone in management were on the same page. The moral was super low across the board. There was also alot of favoritism within the different ranks that was apparent to all. When addressed, management did not seem to care and continued to carry on with business as usual.

title: Waste of time
pros: The only pro I can think that would be in a good light would be the selling to Autonomy. Good thing for them to get out of the software part, they have no clue. Keep collecting those boxes, that about the level you are at.
cons: Bad Bad Bad management Really Bad management No training They use the fact that most of there work force are truck drivers and that's why the benefits are so bad.

title: Good company that historically treated employees well, but is going through transition...
pros: Awesome name recognition in the space as the industry leader in records and information management. Great footprint and reputation for quality service. Flexibility in the workplace and fair compensation.
cons: Little to no diversity in any level up from the bottom layers. Absolutely no diversity or minority representation in management. Business model is changing in ways that negatively affect relationship management employees. Huge layoffs in the last two years. Little to no job security for a company that historically guaranteed it.

title: The best people have left & "tired iron" is all that remain
pros: 800 pound gorilla in physical data protection/records management outstanding Fortune 1000 customer base high profile industry & great brand recongition
cons: strategy and innovation are non-existent -- returning money to the shareholders instead of investing in business the brains and leadership have left or retired - investors treating IRM like an ATM machine sales is dead and Go-to-market expansion is a thing of the past - just managing & retaining business now

title: Rewarding In So Many Ways
pros: Iron Mountain employees are hardworking and dedicated to doing the right thing to service their customers. The organization can provide a long-lasting rewarding career to those that demonstrate the skills to be successful.
cons: Iron Mountain is no different than other companies as it has been impacted by the downturn in the economy. It has some difficult challenges ahead of it, but as the economy improves and the company focuses on it's core business and growth strategy, things will most certainly improve.

title: Going downhill and telling themselves otherwise
pros: Market Leader, deep pockets, can afford the cost of bringing on large accounts, good training,
cons: lost focus of the customer service demands of a company who's top product is service. Invests heavily in a process and executes poorly then scraps the plan resulting in a revolving door of old ideas that result in drastic changes in the comp and sales process Commissions is the most poorly administrated function of the business.

title: Best company I have ever worked for!
pros: My management is easily accessible, understanding and supportive. Great pay. Great benefits.
cons: There have been many layoffs over the past 3 years. It has hurt some morale. No real career path or upward movement plan. Feel like I am in survival mode each year. Layoffs occur October and November each year.

title: Disgusting working condition for women. Sexual harassment is extremely prevalent and unpunished.
pros: None. Every day was a nightmare.
cons: Working here for the past few years I have seen more sexual harassment cases than anywhere else, and have noticed how the HR department sweeps it under the rug. There is close to no gender diversity. Not to mention a lot of upper management will use employees to complete non-work related jobs for personal gain, and charge company money. This is the most unprofessional, irresponsible, and disgusting work environment I have ever experienced. When seeking help, nothing was done, and when asked to be moved to a different department I was shut down and told to remain where I was until they could “find a place,” which never happened. I’ve since moved companies and would NEVER return here. I would highly suggest looking else where.

title: Chaotically Managed
pros: The company remains afloat and the remote work is very convenient.
cons: There are major org changes every other quarter, making it hard to do anything consistently. Internal growth opportunities seem hap hazardous-- the company prefers to hire at the top level from external sources and then they bring in their own people and preferences. Top levels still feel like a boys club.

title: Large Corporation Heading Down
pros: Good benefits Great job out of college
cons: Management Salary Bonus/Commission is almost 1:1 Many employees are out to move up in their roles, there is not much of a focus on the client and providing the front line employees tools to succeed Peter Principle in effect at this org Customer Service/Service is really lacking, many many unhappy clients

title: Salespeople Beware!
pros: Excellent hardworking people on operationally front Flexible schedule for sales Many tenured folks who truly care about the company
cons: Document Storage is a dying industry, plain and simple. Layoffs will continue as industry trends away from paper toward digitization Endless recreating strategy and organization for sales

title: Business Development Executive
pros: There are still some good people left from the glory days of Richard Reese. The old timers have a sense of doing the right thing for the client and value sales. Operations does the best they can with the limited resources and no support from management.
cons: The new growth strategy is to squeeze every penny out of the business from outsourcing all support to Thailand, India etc., setting up unrealistic sales goals and providing operations with all the power to pay as seen fit. If you want to make commission money this is not the place for you. Sales is an after thought with little to no power.

title: Striving to Keep Improving
pros: Iron Mountain does a good job of communicating its mission and core values to the employees, which underscores the expectations on the employees to live those values. They also seem to have a knack for hiring good people whose work habits align with those values. The company does annual employee satisfaction surveys and takes action to address some of the low-scoring areas. Because Iron Mountain is so big, there are a lot of opportunities for growth and advancement. As a result, many of the current employees who have been there more than a few years have held several different positions -- which allows for knowledge sharing and cross-training. The company used to operate in distinct silos, but there are efforts underway to minimize that. There are a lot of opportunities for employees to be rewarded and recognized for their work -- those public pats on the back are important, and something that a lot of companies forget to do.
cons: The organizational chart is a confusing mess, with many many layers of management. It can be difficult to figure out how things operate and how the pieces fit together. The company is years behind in terms of the technology tools employees have to work with. While the benefits package overall is pretty good, the paid time off is very stingy. In a sense, the company culture works counter to the idea of work/life balance -- many people work nights and weekends and during their vacations, and other employees are sometimes given hints that they're not good team players if they have expectations for personal/family time.

title: Great company to work for.
pros: Iron Mountain in Collegeville, PA is a great place to work. The offices are beautiful, the support staff is highly trained, and senior management is easy to access. There is also a cafeteria in house and a gym, which really made working late easy.
cons: Because their are two headquarters, Boston and Collegeville, half the team is in another state. The most senior people are in Boston, so if you are in Collegeville, your opportunities for growth are limited.

title: Great Experience - Middle management could use some development
pros: Support from your VP. VP of FIeld HR was always very supportive and gave credit where it was due. Great place to grow your career and start out.
cons: Middle management in HR lacks ability to relate to staff. East coast staff is very bereaucratic and stereotyped certain team members while West coast field HR Staff seemed to run tighter operations and preached on career development and gave challenging objectives.

title: Former employee, recently laid off
pros: Good benefits. Company is ethical, well-respected, and flexible regarding business needs. Systems and tools are updated regularly. Staff is treated with respect.
cons: Like many companies, support roles are being consolidated or shifted overseas. Company has laid off many employees over the last few years. Front line staff has been trimmed to the bone. Employees are asked to do more, work faster, with fewer resources. At corporate level, much confusion regarding who does what. A lot of passing the buck. I worked for IM for 10 years and was still in the lower end of the salary range for my position. Raises were minimal.

title: Terrible environment. Read the reviews.
pros: Good employee benefits. Good people all around the world.
cons: No career growth. Too many politics. Only those who play the political game will get promoted, regardless of experience. Loyalty, hard work and going the extra mile is not appreciated. Good talent is leaving. Big push to become a major technology company. Keeping customer information secure is becoming a low priority. Unless you are part of the management team, your voice and experience is worth nothing. Your manager will not fight for you. You are a nobody.

title: Is Iron Mountain a good company or not
pros: Iron Mountain has good benefits - Dental, Health Insurance, 401k and a stock purchasing plan - the plans are neither good or bad.
cons: Iron Mountain does not inspire loyalty in it's brand. Thirty year employees are laid off without any type of package deal, just a check for unused vacation time. If you work for Iron Mountain leave as soon as possible

title: Average Company
pros: -Co-workers are very nice usually because they are in the same situation as you are. -The hours are stable.
cons: -Absolutely no room for advancement in the company. The key positions in Iron Mountain are filled from the outside. -Disparity between higher and lower level. -Most positions here do not give you any technical/marketable/high level skills. So you cannot use this company as a stepping stone to a career. -The pay is well below the work they have you do. Expect to work very hard. Nobody at the lower level is happy with their wage. -You have to hit quotes. They will fire you if you cannot hit their ridiculously high quotes. They do not lower quotes. -Everything that goes wrong is your fault. Iron Mountain never admits fault. They will gladly take the credit if something goes right though. -The entire company has a massive ego. Probably bigger than Trumps. - Their databases, websites, and anything IT related are pretty outdated and clunky. This is because they are not able to provide or understand the newest technologies that are being implemented by other companies. -Almost nobody that works here is under 30. Iron Mountain is not very good at attracting young and talented workers. Simply because their benefits and pay cannot match what other places are offering. -They still have a hierarchical structure, which most people argue is not very effective for a company anymore. -The higher ups ask the employees at the bottom to help come up with ideas to make the company more money. Seriously? That is the whole point of an executive position. You get paid to sit there thinking about stuff then go to meetings to talk about the stuff you were thinking about. Simple. - Very little job security. They will fire you or let you go if they feel like it.

title: Huge Transformation Opportunity
pros: Incredibly bright folks, many with decades of experience protecting customer data. New technology leadership and platform adoption, especially in the records management business is sweeping through and making waves. Significant opportunity for people looking to make an outsized impact on a global organization if they have the drive and technical chops to deliver. Organization is well structured to retool and rebrand itself as an agile technology company, with the physical security to back that up. Company has been remote-working for many employees for years, and has had tremendous success during COVID-19 due to wise productivity moves before the pandemic.
cons: Iron Mountain is the collection of several businesses. Records Management is highly outsourced in the technology space, with varying levels of quality. Digital transformation of the back office was starting very late. Customer facing systems are well kept, but organization changes have unsettled the landscape. Working in highly regulated space, with some very serious customers who love to bury you in audits. Be prepared to jump through hoops and put out fires. Not uncommon to hunt for ancient knowledge, as many of the products and platforms are from decades old solutions, which is mostly due to the nature of the business of keeping archives. Longer term concerns that Records Management, i.e.: shredding/document storage business is shrinking due to the digitization of records. Not sure this is really occurring, but the company branching out into datacenter business is a clever move. Many big hyperscalers need facilities, and Iron Mountain is a trusted name.

title: listen to your customers!
pros: I completly enjoyed the benefits package, very strong name reconition in the market. Easy to move ahead, if your numbers , & sales quotas, are met, and consistant!
cons: Most of the Management is very knowledgeable, which helps when your new. The systems they have in olace are a little confusing in the begining as well, mentors are aplenty, that does not mean if your outside of the boys club you will have access to them.

title: Always re-organizing. Some very good people.
pros: Very good people. I think they do well by their customers. Company tries to do the right thing--philanthropy, diversity, etc. I had good access to training for my yearly professional goals. Remote work was well supported for most.
cons: Too much change--always reorging the entire time I was there. Some decisions seemed to be made without enough thought. Some senior managers not really in touch with the day to day life of their employees.

title: micro-management, anyone?
pros: they pay well for many of the positions they offer, and they try to keep the benefits package competitive as possible.
cons: Consultants were brought in to 'help' management learn to manage better, which turned it into a severely micro-managed company. Every minute of every day is tracked, and every action is tracked as well. The data is then used to evaluate who the weakest of the herd is and lay them off. They 'claim' these actions were not for economic reasons, but being a student at the moment, enrolled in an economics class, their actions are a number one example of what companies do to build revenue so they have bigger numbers at year end. For a Fortune 500 company that has seen itself strive during all the major ups and downs of the current economy, I find that line to be nothing more than a lie. When I started with the company, they prided themselves on the Core Values that every employee was to be held to; our Total Customer Service plan has been tossed out the window. The new procedures turn what used to be a 24 hour turn around in response to well over 48 hours, sometimes closer to a week. I fear the company will soon find itself struggling to stay in the Fortune 500, because their employees are just going to stop caring and stop producing the quality of work they once took pride in providing.

title: Good people. Hardworking, caring, dedicated.
pros: As a courier CDL B driver, every day is different and challenging. Enjoy working independently. Management very responsive to concerns. Friendly, hard working crew.
cons: Some days are very long. Management in transportation has always had difficulty maintaining a full staff due to turn over. Customer service has always been a problem despite attempts at improvement. Customer service is the biggest complaint drivers receive from the front line customers.

title: If you can handle working long hours and high stress this is the job for you great company tho overall.
pros: Great benefits, great pay and room for growth, working from home a major plus, open door policy and management great and know how to manage teams.
cons: Long hours working, not much help, not a lot of communication, high stress..

title: Not for seasoned salespeople
pros: good benefits, somewhat flexible hours
cons: negative environment, mediocre pay/comp plan, poor processes, terrible customer service, poor training, micromanaged.

title: Chaotic mess
pros: They allow WFH without a pandemic
cons: This company bought my company, and it was a rough transition. No training, no communication, no path towards success. No one even checked to see if we had access to the correct systems no matter how many times it was requested. We just got yelled at and put on a PIP when we didn't magically divine what we needed to do and how to do it. I stuck it out for 2 years and got an ulcer and an anxiety disorder from my time there.

title: Too many leaders, not enough staff, outsourcing, etc.
pros: Schedule flexibility, work from home, moderately decent salary.
cons: Bonus structure constantly changing making it unachievable to maximize. No salary increases in 5+ years for certain roles. Constant leadership changes. Outsourcing of jobs to India and Phillipines. Closure of Canadian and Pennsylvania based Customer Care Teams to stand up new facility in Georgia (formerly Recall). Too fast of a ramp up with the new staff in GA, so now tons of wait times and incomplete work.

title: Marketing Manager
pros: Remote working option is great. Flexibility to get your work done HR is willing to pay according to average salaries in market....if you take the initiative to ask.
cons: Constant organizational change resulting in many teams, departments and good employees being laid off. You'll live in meetings from 9-5 and will have to find other time to do your "day job" and get actual work done.

title: OLDER STAFF ARE THE FIRST TO GO
pros: Great at storing inactive records at the box level.
cons: Iron Mountain has been on a cost cutting binge for the last few years eliminating older employees especially in sales and staff that were outsourced to work at client sites. I left IM a number of years ago but still stay in contract with my former coworkers who tell me that IM continues laying off senior employees with 20-30 years of service with only a handshake and two weeks of severance pay. IM gives no thought to the dedication and profit these employees generated during their years of service!

title: Strategy Manager
pros: I loved while I was there for 10 years. Even though there was a lot of politics on who got promoted and raises. But I loved what I did and loved my manager and my team
cons: Benefits was pretty bad. Healthcare benefits especially was bad. For a such a big company, they didn't negotiate a good deal.

title: 25,000 Employees Around the World Holding Steady
pros: Iron Mountain is focused more than ever on its culture and its commitment to living its core values of integrity, safety and security, inclusion and teamwork, and taking individual ownership in building customer value. But the CEO bottom lines it as "mates take care of mates," a quote from a frontline employee in Australia when asked what is the best thing about working here. That simple sentence has resonated throughout the company ever since. The culture is about the people.
cons: Benefits are not competitive. Need to do better.

title: Good Company but what will change as a REIT?
pros: Iron Mountain has good management practices with solid policies and procedures without getting overly bureaucratic. I have been at companies with too little structure an ones with too many. Iron Mountain has the best balance of any company I have worked for.
cons: How will the future of the company change as it pursues a REIT structure? Iron Mountain has had it's share of layoffs in the past and have parted ways with many strong performers.

title: Great company culture
pros: Iron Mountain is a great place to work. Great work life balance, working with good people, but that's not to say that you don't work very hard. You are constantly learning new things and developing your career. I'd highly recommend working here.
cons: It takes a while to get up to speed, to learn the procedures and ways to navigate through the company. Onboarding could be more relevant to the actual position you are hired for.

title: Decent Company
pros: Great coworkers and decent pay. Iron Mountain is a good company with a good reputation (from the client perspective), and it is well earned. To this day I look at the Iron Mountain vans, boxes, shredding stations with pride. They also do a lot to keep their employees engaged and in high spirts. Before it was the "politically correct" thing to do, they had several orgs for minorities and the LGBTQIA+ within the company and they truly gave them a voice.
cons: We were all lied to during the interview process about the true nature of the job. It was so egregious that at the end of my 2 years with the company only 5 of the 20+ new hires in my class were left, all of whom were actively applying/interviewing for new jobs. The employee trust in the company was eroded from step one.

title: They say the right things, don't always do the right things.
pros: Very loyal long-term employees; especially on the frontline.
cons: The company talks about employee development, but in reality, it isn't possible because the records management business is run so lean and is in steep decline. There is literally nowhere to grow. Lay-offs are calendarized to take place monthly.

title: Challenging but rewarding!! Great work / life balance.
pros: Management is extremely supportive, which empowers the team to thrive with collaboration. Wonderful place to grow, balance work/life, and deliver a great customer experience. Training is unlimited, resources are always available, and the product(s) are solid. Benefits / PTO / Work-Life balance are above average.
cons: None that I’ve experienced as an employee. I’ve seen bad companies treat employees poorly, and Iron Mountain goes above and beyond to ensure employees are supported.

title: They try but alot of vapor in thier results.
pros: Lower level managers openly share advice and experience. Good opportunities to network within and without the company. Diverse customers allows one to learn about many industries.
cons: Limited structure and leadership. Leadership is very hands off with helicopter approach. Company rushes out initiatives with minimal groundwork put in place resulting in half-baked rollouts that staff and customers must navigate through.

title: Ridiculous Layoffs
pros: Good group of people to work with. Willing to work with employee issues
cons: Too many layoffs. Wrong people laid off. They layoff good people, and keep people that don't contribute.

title: Don't trust what you are told
pros: Great benefits - health and dental Great community support programs and employee activity committees. Loved the blood drives and team participation in community events and 5ks
cons: Upper management doesn't trust the staff to be honest with them. Your staff can take the news if it's bad. They just need to know the reality of the situation so they can plan for the financial security of their family

title: Dependable company
pros: Have shifted to more innovated model Decision making is expected on Local level Opportunity to move up if you are able to relocate Worldwide company Benefits are above average New opportunities are opening up as new lines of business are brought in Focus on safety and continued learning
cons: Still working to change from the top down corporate rut it was in for so long A lot of downsizing in the last 5 years Perks get less and less each year with focus on costs Wages lag behind similar businesses Continually understaffed

title: Strong culture and strategy
pros: Colleagues are amazing to work with. Everyone is kind, smart, helpful and truly collaborative. Teams live our company values. Very inclusive culture. Flexible workplace, strong leadership, clear vision and on a growth journey which is challenging and exciting.
cons: Heath and financial benefits are average.

title: Great Company Still Trying To figure out who they are...
pros: very nice, helpful employees that are dedicated to the company.
cons: countless reorgs that are confusing and damaging to employee morale. Feels like the leaders aren't sure what they want to do or how to do it. A lot of leaders leave within 3 years or less.

title: Decent entry-level work
pros: Multiple shifts are available, with overtime encouraged but not required. Management tries to be decent. Not physically demanding compared to retail, fast food, or manufacturing. Clear directions and procedures to follow. No need to deal with customers of any kind.
cons: Need to be highly detail-oriented. No room for mistakes--you better get it right! Required to follow directions to the letter, which not everyone can do wello.

title: Terrible Management. Terrible Job
pros: There are no positives to working at Iron Mountain.
cons: Management and Manager were awful. Say they respect the "work life balance" but often required you to work 12-15 hour days and if that wasn't done you'd get in trouble. Training and onboarding were a joke. There was a lack of focus and help when you had questions. Direct manager was never in the office to provide help. If you needed help you would have to call and hope to reach them. If you didn't reach them no one else would offer support for fear of being wrong and not doing what the manager expected. I do not suggest this company to anyone.

title: I toiled for a multinational data protection company and learned that data security is important for individuals, too.
pros: There was an adequate training regiment in place and the supervisors were will qualified and dedicated. The hours were flexible and the pay was reasonable.
cons: There was no actual opportunity for advancement within the company. You were pretty much stuck at the level in which you entered. The best chances for improving one's lot came through relocating to another state.

title: Good ole Boys
pros: Good benefits and they have a large network so you can move around the country and have good processes in place to support the business.
cons: Higher level jobs are dealt out based on who you know and as long as you are willing to follow what their vision is. No true entrepreneurship opportunities. To advance, become buddies don't worry about work effort or quality.

title: Ok place to work
pros: Its a huge company with many places all over the world in case you want to move to another state or country. pay and vacation is decent.
cons: They hire bosses from outside the company who know little or nothing about the business. also they constant have you starting and stopping different projects and then complaining when they aren't done on time.

title: Excellent company, good pay, a LOT of transition
pros: Benefits start at Day 1, good 401k match, a lot of potential for internal movement. Open door policy. Great people, excellent cafeteria. Bonuses are very good: quarterly for Customer Care, yearly for other positions
cons: For one thing, the company has made about 2,000 layoffs world-wide in the last 6 months. Still a good company to work for, but I'd be leery about job security. Maybe it'll be better once the current round of layoffs dies down. The internal command structure can also be very confusing, with people reporting to different people depending on current projects.

title: They do not appreciate their employees.
pros: The only great thing about working at Iron Mountain is that they give quarterly bonuses but who knows how long they will last with the direction the company is taking.
cons: Recent lay off, out sourcing, disorganization, micro managing, no clear career path, they say one thing and do another. To top it off, you can receive excellent quality review scores and leave on good terms with the company but the HR policy does not allow managers to provide references or letters of recommendation.

title: Over 10 years experience in multiple corporate positions
pros: Employees at Iron Mountain have a lot of passion, they really care about the company's strategy and growth and providing quality service to the customers.
cons: Constant change (this can be both good and bad). Sometimes there is a lack of clear priorities and conflicting priorities across the various departments / geographies. There is a tendancy to try to tackle too many things at once and resources are tapped out.

title: Good Company!
pros: Great work-life balance, Iron Mountain understands that your family has a priority. Great attitude makes for a low-stress, happy work day. Also good job security, this company isn't going anywhere and there are many job opportunities and they promote from within. Bonuses for ALL employees when earned on a territory bases.
cons: Annual raises are minuscule. If you don't want to wait years to get promoted, you'll need to take advantage of their tuition reimbursement and get a degree.

title: A company that you can stand behind
pros: Company that offers a service that is needed world wide. They will always be one of the top companies in the document/records storage business always growing in the right direction to keep up with their customers needs. Decent wages and rewards for performers. Flexible with work/life challenges. Offers training but one needs to be proactive and take ownership in their career and take advantage of the opportunities.
cons: Can be difficult to promote oneself with new jobs internally - but that is true with most companies.

title: Senior Business Development Executive, Healthcare
pros: Stable company in the sales division, especially on the National and Vertical teams.
cons: Iron Mountain is an Operations company - not a sales company. Sales compensation is clunky and this is not a forecasting/bookings culture. Though efforts are being made to change that, Sales clearly takes a back seat to Ops.

title: Exempt
pros: Good balance between corporate beuracracy and individual free thinking. Lots of room for lateral advancement and the skill building that entails that kind of movement.
cons: Dying business. Hard to see them succeeding in the future without radical core business transformation. Moving up is possible but not probable. Comp used to be good, not so much anymore.

title: Shady Management
pros: Skeleton Crew so you get to know your peers well since your over worked.
cons: Management never leaves ivory tower to see or help employees.. Routes are 11 hours a day but your pushed to do it in 9 hours or your considered a failure. One TSS with no helper is expected to pick-up between 150 and 500 boxes a day. During 100 miles of driving and 20 stops! Office politics are ridiculous! And coordinator doesn't leave his desk but pushes the couriers to the brink of quiting.

title: Great on the outside, sub par on the inside
pros: Huge global company, remote working, some teams are better than others, tuition reimbursement plan for $5K/ year.
cons: Changes brand and vision every few years, most employees are stuck in their ways, takes 12 months and a sacrifice to the gods to get something fixed/changed.

title: Data Management
pros: Many employees have been with the company for years and are totally committed to the success of those around them and how they can help.
cons: Late to the table at determining the technology and solutions which will promote growth and leverage the great customer base and trust they have. Many systems are antiquated and manual causing customer and employee frustration.

title: Poor work ethic
pros: Benefits, over time, flexible work schedule, PTO, chance to move up or around the company.
cons: Recently, IRM change their annual review date so they gave lower increases. Management from Operation Managers to supervisors favor certain employees. Many employees are allowed to roam around the building, take longer than 15 minutes on break or an hour on lunch. Management has given more work to their best employees then the ones who are roaming around the building. If you complain to management or to human resource, you are mistreated or complaints are ignored.

title: Great Opportunity
pros: I loved my team and my direct Leadership Team. Great benefits and a wonderful career opportunity.
cons: Annual adjustment to volumes and adjusting to those needs, which means annual release of staff to adjust to the demands. The contract I managed was not renewed and there was no available opportunity. Honestly, that's just business.

title: Great training program
pros: Iron Mountain provides a great training program for new hires in the customer response/issue resolution departments. It is set up exactly how I learn new concepts so it was definitely a plus for me.
cons: Management seems to be pretty strict on the work schedule. I understand this is necessary to service the customers appropriately but allowing a little leniency would be preferred from the employees perspective.

title: Not great not the worst
pros: Good selection of products to sell and decent payout on some of the solutions. Not a lot of micromanaging, seems you can sometimes sell nothing an entire year without anyone saying something.
cons: Commissions system is broken and leadership has struggled to stay in place. Go to market on cloud and advanced solutions was beyond lacking.

title: A Total Joke of a Company
pros: Very, very little if anything
cons: No management at all on second shift; everyone just does whatever they want with no manager present. If you are a minority, you have it made. You can walk in whenever you want, go home when you want, take a break when you want and just about do next to nothing and get paid. If you aren't a minority, you will work hard to make up the slack.

title: A Company in Transition
pros: High profit margins and a strong market presence. Most employees have been there for a long time and really understand the business. The Iron Mountain name is fairly well respected.
cons: The company lacks senior management vision to mature the business any further which is why the investors are reorganizing it into a REIT. Their core business (box storage and shred) can not grow much more even with acquisitions.

title: Lots of issues
pros: Flexible schedule, when they let you. Better than being unemployed
cons: Low pay, infighting among teams, lack of clear answers and strategy, very political environment. Only those who play politics get promoted. Most managers have no training and will throw you in front of bus to save their job.

title: ....and the cuts continue....
pros: local colleagues are great, sense of family is the norm.
cons: Almost too many to list. So many cuts in Operations that quality is being severely affected. Mistakes being made, and customers are suffering as a result. Sales targets set so high that only 20% of salesforce hit them last year, yet they went up again this year. The organization is in chaos, they don't stick with a strategic plan more than 6 months before they start changing it yet again.

title: Industry Leader but not progressive enough
pros: Opportunity to create and manage projects Efficient - Process improvement is consistent Leadership training and education opportunities
cons: Maintains status quo for hourly staff education Challenging environment for the few women at mid-management level in the market I worked in. Limited advancement opportunities Inconsistent education for hourly staff

title: Project Manager
pros: They were a great team environment. It's the definition of work hard and play hard. The people are well tenured so job security isn't a problem.
cons: It you're looking for flexibility or a better work/life balance, this probably isn't the place for you. There is a lot of silo mentality and sometimes that supercedes what's best for the customer.

title: Iron Mountain needs to change.
pros: The only positive aspect of working for Iron mountain is that you get to manage your own time and get to work independently.
cons: The cons is sometimes you don't get a lunch break and there is no growth within the company when it came to my department. Also the management team was not supportive when it came to issues at work. My manager was not supportive or didn't want to adjust employees schedule when it came to going to school.

title: Great company! Industry leader.
pros: They are invested in their people. They provide quality training. They have good opportunities for growth. They have a good benefits package. Very good internal resources and teams to help close new business and manage sales activities.
cons: Needs to re-focus on the future. There are in a transformation stage. There are a lot of layers to management. Upper management is new so the path is uncertain. Constant change within the management ranks during the last several years.

title: Unorganized - Management Unprofessional
pros: Co-workers are mostly friendly, uniforms supplied, salary not bad for some positions.
cons: Newest manager is a nut job...verbally abusive and rude a lot of times, throwing things, calls unnecessary meetings frequently, reminds employees constantly that he's the boss. VERY unprofessional in actions and appearance. Doesn't have respect of the employees because of the way he acts.

title: Overall a good company to work for - if you keep your job
pros: Good location; can work from home; Different areas that you can move into. Co-workers are friendly and good.
cons: Jobs being sent off-shore. Management takes pride in being unemotional and cold. Roles are very specific so getting anything done internally takes a large team.

title: Great potential but leaders not addressing real issues
pros: Nice, well-meaning people; strong culture of doing the right thing; belief in talent as strategy; strong financial management; commitment to social responsibility.
cons: Gap between intent and execution. Very risk averse; old boy network, especially in the field; too many people who have only worked at Iron Mountain/stuck in tradition; too much DIY for employees to function efficiently (and happily).

title: Fulfillment Specialist/ Print Specialist
pros: I worked here for 7 years. The work was simple and the hours of operation were good. Typical 9-5 with some occasional overtime with weekends and holidays off.
cons: Management and employees were unprofessional. There was always some type of drama. Management showed a lot of favoritism and did not promote within the company enough. It was extremely hot during the summer in the warehouse and extremely cold in the winter. Pay was not good and the annual raises were horrible. Bounses became non existent.

title: Family Environment Work Place
pros: The people I worked with were more than coworkers. They became family. I have never had a job where I felt so at home.
cons: This job was a temp position. We were hired on to clear out a warehouse for resale to a developer. I surely will miss working there.

title: Mobile Shredder Driver
pros: Iron mountain was a very good company to work for. I enjoyed my time there and the management and my co workers were great. They pay and benefits package as an employee was very good.
cons: The only concern I had for this position was scheduling. My customer base was too far open and there was no way to get all my orders done in a timely manner.

title: Analyst
pros: Great people to work with, everyone is very friendly and for the most part approachable. Great hours most of the time & flexibility.
cons: Company is very slow at making decisions, most people will just refer you to someone else when you ask for help so seems to take forever to figure something out, teams/departments do not communicate making you have to tell the appropriate parties across teams, a lot of the times just seems like a very inefficient company. It can be frustrating for the employees.

title: RUN Away- Don't Waste Your Time On This Place
pros: Benefits, Salary, Interview Was Fairly Easy
cons: Was told on my first day "Not to bring a butter knife to a fight" by the IT guy. This was when I went to pickup my equipment. Made no sense. Unprofessional at best! I asked to use the restroom and was told I could wait. Really? I am sorry but I am not a child and who do you think you are!?!?

title: Run. Far away
pros: OT possibilities but don’t hold your breath.
cons: As far as their Dallas location on Pinnacle point - it needs a serious overhaul. Managers and coordinators donor care about lower level employees. They spread lies. And if they don’t “personally” like you they will make it hell. You can even have a family member commit suicide and they do not care. You can walk by any coordinator and catch them speaking poorly of you. It’s like a high school with a bunch of little girls running the show. They will even keep you as temp or contract, but when it is time for permanence they throw you away.

title: Good company, good pay, constant changes.
pros: Our department has good communication so that everyone knows what's going on. No secrets between any of the levels of management. There are opportunities for working on different projects so things are always interesting.
cons: There are been three layoffs in the past three years. There is a search for a new CEO and therefore there is some sense of not knowing where we will be focusing in the coming year.

title: I loved working for Iron Mountain In Tennessee, In Michigan not so much
pros: In Tennessee people where great, hours were awesome. I was taught a lot and fit right in with everyone.
cons: In Michigan I went home crying after my first day. People were rude and had to do a lot of traveling. I was pregnant and they asked me to move heavy file boxes.

title: Employees Do Not Matter
pros: Good pay, decent amount of time off, easy work if you are a driver or work on the data protection side (back-up tapes, computer media, hard drives, etc.). DO NOT get trapped working in the paper warehouse.
cons: Management will find an excuse to fire employees rather than lay them off when work slows down or a new business is bought and integrated.

title: TOP HEAVY
pros: Enjoyed the work itself. Customers were generally nice. Initial training however was a bit disorganized so you had to learn by experience. Benefits were better than average.
cons: Staff reductions of hourly workers in favor of more layers of management severely damaged level of service to the customers and led to low worker morale. Company management never really understood how important basic good service at a fair price was to it's customers.

title: Going through changes
pros: - Great pay and benefits - Large organization with many layers and established teams - Strong financial health - Records management leader
cons: - Industry changing to digital, company moving to REIT focus away from physical storage - Middle leadership given too long to fail before changes are made, slow to react, and too detached/oblivious to what is takes to execute plans - Operations team not efficient but think they are

title: New direction for the company
pros: Great people to work with, If you have a question or need help someone will be there for you, the work from home policy is terrific, nice location in downtown Boston
cons: Constant changes in management and organization, hard to advance your career, jobs are starting to be off-shored to India, not many vacation days.

title: Marketing
pros: Flexible work schedule. You can work from home or become a remote employee. Great benefits including a LiveWell program to encourage healthy behavior. They also provide a lot of opportunity to expand your skill set and enhance your professional career. The people are intelligent and fun to work with.
cons: Management is a mess. I was uncertain about my job almost every month. There is always rumor of another layoff or reorg.

title: Great company, lots of change
pros: Great company, it is wonderful to work for the industry leader. Lots of growth and new ventures to new business and worldwide service offerings. Used to have many awards, team building days, and trips, now there are only some awards and trips for higher up sales people.
cons: Lots of changes to account management and positions leaves you constantly looking over your shoulder. Overseas customer service is bad Difficult to move up

title: Micro Managed
pros: Good benefits. Growing company. Management is safe, but that's about it.
cons: You will be micromanaged every day. The communication in this company is terrible, from the top to the bottom. Over the past 2 years they've laid off a lot of people for cheaper overseas options. They hire temps from time to time, only to keep a few for a month or 2. Impossible to better your career, they constantly hire from the outside

title: Regional Sales Director
pros: 2005-2011 was a great time for Iron Mountain. Client growth and acquisition mode along with introducing several transition services to the offering.
cons: Very political environment. Operations thought they ran sales and tried. Career opportunities were limited.

title: Started out great but ended poorly
pros: Some great people work/worked here
cons: Unfortunately their business model isn't sustainable and they are searching for a way to be relevant. With their new focus, that might happen, but its going to take a sec to play out. Their was a lot of high level turnover, which caused a lot of uncertainty and a lack of direction, causing a lot of people to leave, followed by a mass layoff, which wasn't handled very well.

title: Decent place to work - management direction poor
pros: interesting projects work with smart people using innovative methods good work life balance very stable revenue stream from physical records side of the business
cons: Sr. Management in the digital division is weak Good people managers not valued People are pigeonholed in their positions - breaking out is discouraged

title: I had a great time with the company, until my job was outsourced...it felt like a family there
pros: Creating budgets, working with outside consultants, great people to work with
cons: The only thing I might have an issue with is top management has a hard time being transparent in regards to upcoming lay-offs...

title: Not what I hoped it would be
pros: Independent work environment. Managers only bugged you if you didn't do your job.
cons: The training was far too long, and mostly self-taught via outdated web presentations. The actual job differed significantly from the job description. It basically boiled down to being a telemarketing position.

title: we've been lied to.
pros: I WAS a satisfied, hard working employee and felt my direct supervisor had a real interest in my growth and performance.
cons: DBA consultants changed the entire company attitude. Customer service is last, numbers and production are number 1. The employee is no longer valued and in fact looked at as a liability. Micro-management is in place and employees who have dedicated years with stellar reviews are being tossed out the door like garbage.

title: There were good & bad things..
pros: I was able to work independently and was given the opportunity to learn a variety of different skills. Some managers were terrific to work with & really helped me to develop my career.
cons: There were some managers who did not know what they were doing. There was a lot of productivity standards that were very difficult to meet. Some behavior was excused when one person did it, but not the other.

title: Sales
pros: Wealth of features and benefits for customer use and solution selling. Global footprint, strong protocols for information security. Salary and compensation is competitive with excellent benefits.
cons: Highly reactive culture. Frequent changes of direction. Fragmented decision making. Internal competition is a distraction from core values. Poor coordination of initiatives across the organizations resulting in competing priorities. Field sales and account management expected to fix systemic problems outside of their control. Customer experience is not an easy one.

title: Good company-if you like constant change
pros: The company has great perks like working from home in certain positions and benefits are great.
cons: In the handful of years I was there there was constant fear of being laid off among the company employees. Since the company is publicly traded and shareholders are always looking for the top dollar, it feels as though money is extremely more important than employees.

title: Pluses and Minuses to every company
pros: Great people to work with, and the company truely lives up to its core values. Plus you can work from home in most positions full-time
cons: The pay for IT jobs is very under market and the department is very under staffed. It is hard to keep up with the workload, let alone improve things.

title: Overall great job with some not so pleasant supervisors to work with.
pros: Great job stability, unfortunately not many advancement opportunities unless you have a 4 year degree with no experience. Like most companies they would rather hire John Doe fresh from college with no experience with the company than the person that has been with the company 10+ years.
cons: No career advancement unless you have a degree, and know some people on the inside.

title: Company in flux
pros: Solid business revenue foundation. Flexible work from home option for many locations.
cons: Going through extreme culture and organizational changes as they move towards being a global company.

title: MICROMANAGEMENT
pros: Relatively decent health and dental benefits. Company uniform to includes work boots and jackets for all season.
cons: Too much micromanagement and lower end workers are not allowed to make simple decisions. Method of tracking daily task is more a hindrance than being productive. Not enough minority in upper management.

title: Sales
pros: Lots of opportunity, supportive management, ability to make a good living. 401K health care and other benefits are solid.
cons: Competing metrics from one group to the next. Not always interested in what's best for the customer if it interferes with specific metrics the managers are graded by. In other words the company can seem inflexible at times.

title: Positive experience from a long-time employee
pros: Dynamic work environment. Always something new going on with challenging opportunities. I worked with many great professionals over many years. The company is very focused on delivering shareholder value.
cons: The Company is going through a lot of change in its OH functions which has affected headcount. On the positive side, the company does a great job telegraphing the change in advance and assisting employees in transition with benefits.
