title: Do not waste your time applying for a job here
pros: Co-workers. The co-workers were the only thing that made working here bearable.
cons: Managers and above is very suspect in their leadership. Only look to hire favorites for leadership roles and not the people who have the experience and deserve the job. Put way to much value into the interview part and not the accomplishments of the employee when hiring for roles. Pay is embarrassingly low for what they expect out of you and expect you to accomplish.

title: Good Company - Weak Strategy
pros: Excellent Salary, Industry Leader, Excellent Operations Globally and Nationally. Iron Mountain is the best at what they do and has a global footprint.
cons: High Management turnover, Risk adverse, Needs Vision for growth other than acquisition of other industry competitors. Needs to be more flexible going after business.

title: Terrible....
pros: Flexible work from home options, good benefits, good 401k match, good tuition reimbursement program
cons: Very rarely are females promoted into anything above a manager position. They saddle you down with mundane work and Non-Promotable tasks. They make the rules up as they go and apply them when convenient. They have no problem with the pay scale being driven off of scope, yet FORCE employees to work far above scope.

title: Army Culture
pros: Hours range from 45-55 hours a week No weekends Pay is ok putting in 10 hours of overtime a week
cons: Management tries to run it like the Army They hire mostly military for supervisor or management positions with no experience, and they last maybe 6 months to a year. If you run a route it's better to keep running that route because once they switch you, you will be stuck catching up on others work they did not complete.

title: IRM - good place to work.
pros: Great people, growing and transforming company. Mostly very hard working people with a minimum of slackers. Low percentage of "jerks" working there. Strong teamwork.
cons: Slow decision making sometimes. Talent identification and mgmt can be inconsistent between divisions. Pay scales can vary dramatically for the same role in different depts.

title: No stable
pros: It's a company that is changing a lot in a very short time. A good moment to be in the company to learn about the strategic thinking behind a structural change.
cons: Poor communication with the employees because the future of the company is not clear.

title: Poor Management and continuous layoff have resulted in negative moral.
pros: Made some good career friends.
cons: Several years when I started it was a great place to work with promise of career growth. Now it is a dead end, you only get promoted if Mgmt likes you. The RM area is a joke. The last 2 year they cannot keep experienced employees - the doors keep revolving in Boston or Collegeville/Royersford and part of it is POOR Mgmt.

title: It was wonderful experience they did want me to leave
pros: Benefits, Hours, pay, and compensation / rewards to get for being such a hardworking enthusiastic employee.
cons: Operating some of the equipment the culture and dealing with the strenuous labor that comes with the job

title: Stay far away from this company
pros: I have nothing positive to say about this company.
cons: Not a good shredding service company if you need them to service several locations for your company. Constant missed pick ups, no one pays attention to special requests. Takes 3 separate requests just to have a simple suite number updated. The issues are endless and customer service seriously needs to get their act together.

title: 8 out of 10
pros: Work to life balance was good. Management had no issue letting me work from home. People were easy to get along with.
cons: IM over extending itself with the acquisition of Recall lead to a lot of layoffs, including mine. Bonus part was they gave us all a really decent severance package. I was fortunate enough to only be out of work for 3 weeks.

title: Land of constant restructure
pros: Good benefits, 401K match, stock options
cons: Constant restructure with position eliminations without plan or consideration of long term employees.

title: Run away - fast
pros: if you want a pay check its OK until they decide you are expendable
cons: Beware of DeWolf. They will make Iron Mountain life unbearable. Reducing you job to mindless data entry with use of common sense and brain cells are not permitted. Log your bathroom time on your action sheet and don't forget to smile. Any sort of questions are viewed as agressive and unwarranted. Open door policy is used to weed out the trouble makers and not constructive criticism.

title: Great experience
pros: 1. Great place to learn and get the experience 2. Management is very supportive and helpful 3. Appreciate independent working and working as a team 4. Gives excellent importance to the quality of their material
cons: I believe more training is necessary to improve the standards of your organization present and in the future.

title: Disorganized and unprofessional environment - look elsewhere
pros: Some good people, but they don't stay too long
cons: This company is always going thru re-org. That means lots of good people get laid off, and lots of lousy people stay on. It also means you'll get a new manager at least 1x a year. It's exhausting and tedious. Way too many cooks in the kitchen, making it impossible to get anything done. Additionally, there is no allegiance to the employee. You are just a number. There is NO culture to speak of. There isn't even a real HR team ... it's all outsourced.

title: Don’t even think about it
pros: The people actually doing the work are great. Kind, warm, welcoming, and want to do the right thing.
cons: I don’t understand how leadership can be so toxic, at such high levels. It permeates down and impacts so many, in so many ways. Interview here at your own risk.

title: Growth & Learning
pros: In my experience IM has been a place of growth, support, innovation (albeit not cutting edge) and collaboration. You're not restricted by "chain of command" to solve problems which speeds up solutions tremendously. If you do your job well, it is recognized and valued.
cons: Like all large organizations, there are guardrails to protect you and the organization that sometimes get in the way of what you may consider common sense or an easier path.

title: Terrible management -
pros: Co-workers are great and make the job tolerable.
cons: I have been with Iron Mountain for many years and have managed to survive with the massive layoffs they have every year. Many good individuals let go. Management only cares about how long you have been on the phone and how many calls you make. Its quantity over quality.

title: Manager
pros: The benefit structure was really good. The people themselves are really a pleasure to work with. There is good job security if you can get in the door to begin with.
cons: There is too much red tape throughout the organization. Getting something done requires going through several departments and there are too many silos between them. People are interested in protecting their turf.

title: Production Imaging Coordinator
pros: My co-workers were very nice to work with.
cons: Upper Management doesn't give a crap about the employees. It's all about being the biggest Records Storage Facility world wide, not about the people who work the jobs in order for the company to grow. No decent pay nor any recognition.

title: Sorry to leave
pros: Loved working at Iron Mountain -- solid benefits, nice office (Boston), good people, and terrific work life balance including robust mobile employee program. Left due to a layoff, but was very happy there.
cons: Not as much flexibility if you are not at a corporate location.

title: Great company
pros: Worked with some really great people. Overall most everyone was helpful and team oriented. It is an international company with multiple and emerging business lines so there is opportunity to grow and work in a global environment. Senior management was open and fair.
cons: The company is in the midst of significant change so there is some uncertainty in regards to future outlook. If all goes close to plan it should emerge stronger.

title: iron Mountain Review
pros: Good people, I knew what was expected of me, and the work wasn't too difficult or demanding, but it was a bit monotonous
cons: Uncertainty about job security (I was a temp) Work was off and on, would have liked something with more stability

title: Iron Mountain
pros: Company culture is awesome. Some of the people are fun but still get business handledays. They have a pretty loyal client base.
cons: Management will overlook people in the company ready to be promoted and bring in people who know nothing about the company that disrupt the culture and doesnt know the work.

title: Operations Manager
pros: Compensation was fair. Benefits were average; could get expensive for family coverage. I met some good people through the years.
cons: Company has been in a continual state of reorganizing the last four years; there is absolutely no job security there.

title: What a mess
pros: Flexibility to work from home a lot which was needed for my sanity towards the end of my tenure there.
cons: You won’t move up unless you are into office politics. Company was constantly coming up with new initiatives and plans to transform and never followed through. Lack of process and teamwork throughout the organization. Everyone was overworked and under appreciated.

title: Great Company
pros: The company has grown and matured over the 20+ years I have been here. Equality, diversity, I am heard and my voice has value is only one of the areas. Iron Mountain will provide you the resources, mentoring, and path for advancement when you put in the work to better yourself and grow professionally and personally.
cons: No real cons, this is a great company and room for growth. The potential for caring dedicated people is unlimited.

title: Good Job, but boring
pros: Ok Salary Ok Team, pretty friendly, no ego Not much politics Good bonuses 3 weeks vacation time interesting new projects
cons: Sometimes job could be really boring, a lot of bureaucracy, IT kind of sucks and really slow at resolving issues

title: Good place to work, but lack of direction
pros: There are lots of good people with work ethics. The location is very good if you take the T/commuter rail, and company subside part of the public transportation cost. Work schedule is flexible. Works are challenging and interesting.
cons: Lack of direction from upper management. Poor decision making sometime. Communication between groups could have been better.

title: A typical internship
pros: It was a friendly atmosphere and I had the ability to ask a lot of questions. Hours were typical and work was not overbearing.
cons: Some of the senior management were catty towards the younger staff; at times you could definitely feel the divide between older and younger employees.

title: OK Pay & W/L Balance, Boring Projects, No Upward Mobility
pros: Many opportunities to do new things/work on new projects -- let's just hope you're interested in them, if not, you'll be stuck doing them anyway.
cons: Tons of budget cuts -- all about reducing spend, at whatever cost. You're expected to do a lot with a little (resources, systems, budget, etc.).

title: Amazing people
pros: People who care about doing great work for their customers and who have each other's backs. Company also cares deeply about the community.
cons: It's a slow growth business, and that means that some parts of the business have to shrink in order for it to continue to grow profits.

title: Business Development Executive
pros: Flexible schedule. Minimal Micro-Management. Protected territories. Instant 401k company match. Quick sales cycle. Company promotes cross-selling between internal channels.
cons: In my opinion, commission checks need to be double checked by rep, periodically not 100% accurate when paid out. Upper management hires poor sales managers that cannot lead. Operations team need a fresh slate. Growth opportunities are not visible.

title: Top Employer To Work For!
pros: Iron Mountain is embarking on a MAJOR growth journey. They are becoming a much larger, fast growing, and people-centric global company. Now is an amazing time to be part of this organization: New leadership moving in, Career Development Opportunities, and they are Building a great culture.
cons: Iron Mountain use G-Suite instead of Microsoft 365. Please switch back to Microsoft!!

title: Iron Mountain is always changing!
pros: Great people to work with and a very secure company.
cons: Main focus is the shareholders, not employees. Always looking to be the first to introduce solutions to the market even if they are not ready to support it internally. Poor billing/invoicing system!

title: IT is a mountain
pros: Ability to work on a variety of technology that you typically wouldn't be able to in a larger organization.
cons: Long hours, not enough resources to get things done. Iron Mountain lacks in execution and simply relies on its try and true box business but for technology they are unable to progress.

title: Enterprise Account Manager
pros: Very solid organization, well respected with a great competitive advantage. We negotiated from a good position of strength and our customers very much needed our services. The company was always fairly strong operationally and had good management in most areas of the country.
cons: Often you worked in a vacuum if your accounts didn't merit senior level attention. There were times when I went more than a month without hearing from my director.

title: Micro Management
pros: Training and communication from management is very poor. Untrustworthy/ management practices are common, lying by managers and employees is common.
cons: There is no knowledge base to research best practices, most customers can't create a backup plan without help. Some customers who don't back up financial records get fired. Be prepared for all sorts of insanity. I would NEVER AGAIN work for Iron Mountain. The IT group spy's on everyone. It's done without permission and is illegal.

title: Good Potential/ Bad Management
pros: Active, different daily tasks, freedom to operate independently without help from management
cons: unrealistic metrics, as expectations and responsibility become higher - no reward or motivation to go above and beyond. under-staffed/ no chance of 'getting ahead' and will only get behind causing short cuts throughout management decisions.

title: totally out of their league in the DIGITAL business
pros: for young sales guns who want to hustle OK $$ can be made. Not a glitzy business but steady.
cons: Too many changes to compensation plans over the last few years.

title: Sending IT to India
pros: Great work from home policy.
cons: Leadership is all over the place - no consistent direction. Outsourcing more and more of I.T. to India is not a strategic vision - it's short sighted!

title: Ever Changing Always the Same
pros: Great solid company of you agree to the specialized roles and culture.
cons: istent work and always challenging. Good safety culture and benefits.

title: Lack of communication
pros: Good hard working employees. Customers are appreciative.
cons: In the Iron Mountain mission statement, Shareholders are listed first, employees are listed last. It is rare that an employee makes it to full rate. Employees are made to feel guilty for using sick time. Human resources is outsourced so it is difficult to get any kind of help.

title: Great Team work
pros: The company has great innovative ideas, good collaboration, and a great training environment for employees. This is a great opener for college graduates looking to move up or get their feet wet.
cons: Benefits, low pay, training, equipment, too many bosses, to many complainers. Departments need to work together instead of bashing each other performance to get cudos.

title: Company at a cross roads
pros: I still believe there is a lot of potential at Iron Mountain depending on what the new CEOs vision is once Richard Reese steps down.
cons: Business is changing and paper will someday no longer be as important. Reminds me of Polaroid before digital photography took off.

title: Ok , they offer drivers alot of overtime yet its hard to work around family and school time.
pros: Alot of overtime. , pay is 1.5 times after you reach 40 hours for that work pay week.
cons: Overtime with weather heat can be too much at times. You are only off once you get all of your work done.

title: WOW!! Didn't learn the lessons from the 2011 layoffs?
pros: There are none at Iron Mountain anymore... I was laid off in 2011 which turned out to be the best thing that ever happened to me!!
cons: Everything has been outsourced and continues to be.

title: Not so great experience
pros: Some very good people, very good at what they do and many have been with the firm long term, remote work option good as well, pay at industry rate
cons: Lost in space, no management guidance, strategic direction uncertain, very political culture where few are focused on customer because they are jockeying for position

title: Client Relationship Executive
pros: Company tries to do right by employees, even if they make a decision and it's not well received they attempt to change it to accommodate the employee population
cons: Sales team are segmented out. Management is okay but . A lot of constant change and no room to advance.

title: ok nothing special..
pros: Paychecks come on time every two weeks, and benefits are good.
cons: Over worked and underpaid. Metric driven company that ask its employees to work 50-60 hours a week. No advancement in this company unless you sit in or near Boston near headquarters. Company is very political, and has a good old boy mentality. Records business is dying, focus is shifting towards data centers. CEO is out of touch with business. Layoffs yearly... You have been warned!

title: Good Work Place
pros: The people are great to work with and the food in the building is extremely affordable. Departments are somewhat silo'd and there isn't too much interaction between them. Overall company culture is great and the work/life balance is perfect.
cons: Again, silo'd departments and sometimes the days can feel stiff as an intern. It's hard for them to on-board you onto real projects if you're only there for a given amount of time.

title: Blah
pros: Co workers were all cool got along great meet new clients keeping good relationships with them
cons: No room for advancement, killed the good drivers with ALOT of work gave the lazy people nothing to do

title: Favorites chosen by sr. management. Quite often credit for your hard work is taken by someone else.
pros: Pay is competitive, you do have the ability to work with great systems.
cons: Lots of politics, can be very cut throat at the top.

title: Not too happy working at Iron Mountain
pros: I enjoy working my co-workers. Iron Mountain provides me with a paycheck. Some good benefits.
cons: Many cons: 1) Poor leadership. Within the past year in Sacramento many managers and supervisors have come and gone (whether it be getting fired, quitting or getting demoted). The people at the top do not know how to choose the right leadership team. 2) No room for job advancement or growth. I know many people that I work with that want to learn more and try to better themselves so they could move up within the company but management only choose who they want, not based on job knowledge, skills or competence. They basically choose who they like so there is a lot of favoritism that goes on within the company. 3) Poor communication. Three employees recently got transferred to another Iron Mountain facility and there was no mention of it from management. There are so many questions...why did they get transferred, are we downsizing, are we losing business, who is going to get let go next? So much for open communication between upper management and employees. 4) Numbers.....that's all they care about. How many actions can you get in 8 hours? I know that performance is important for any company but employees are getting injured and many mistakes are happening because many of them are taking short cuts just to try to meet the company's daily quotas. Maybe the company should focus on something else..like giving the customer what they want (customer service at the company is not too good). I could probably list a few more cons but I think I'll stop here for now.

title: Nice people, good place, needs love
pros: Great place to work. People there are friendly and always willing to help. Good for someone just starting out. Management is very approachable. Department structures are consistently changing.
cons: Company likes to throw people "in the deep end" rather then continuously train. They only allow raises once a year. Department structures are consistently changing.

title: Great People
pros: Great Product and service to offer the customer and a consultative approach to selling Great Benefits Ability to work independently
cons: Too Many changes not really sure of the direction they want to take. Not really interested in servicing the small to medium size business Went to servicing customers via the phone.

title: Massive layoffs
pros: The company has fair to good pay. They have great incentives with perks and benefits. Located worldwide so you can transfer positions. There is a detailed corporate training program that helps you learn the organization.
cons: The organization had some major downsizing and layoffs recently. The management team was weak after the layoffs; critical departments and customers suffered. The warehouses were not as organized for storage as they should have been.

title: Temporary Place to work
pros: The work environment is fast pace. You are always learning new things and dealing with challenges on the go.
cons: There is little to no career opportunities. With the way the record management/shredding industry is structured there is not any consistent stream of revenues. As a result, there are rarely any promotions or increase in pay checks. In addition, it results in employees having there career be stagnant and in decline.

title: Good work/life balance, pay could be better
pros: Work/life balance Good benefits (health insurance, dental, vision, 50% 401(k) match up to 5%) Colleagues are friendly and professional, whether at corporate office or in the field Business casual dress code
cons: No great opportunities for advancement Under increased cost-cutting pressure resulting in fewer resources, more work for current employees without corresponding increase in pay Salaries are below market

title: Good company to work for
pros: Friendly work environment, open communication, generally transparent, well-defined roles and responsibilities, and good work culture. Would recommend this company, any location.
cons: Work hours can be long sometimes and intense, work can become stressful - reason could be unpredictable market needs, but relay of information to ground staff can be delayed due to hierarchy, chain of command.

title: It's about the culture!
pros: The culture at Iron Mountain is so special. People really care about one another, and the company values hold up year after year. I was impressed to hear that in Q1 2022, 49% of new hires were women.
cons: It's a global company, and with Covid travel restrictions, we don't get to see our colleagues in other countries face to face as we might have pre-pandemic.

title: Avoid this pyramid scheme if you can.
pros: Stable hours and pay Decent amount of time off
cons: -Almost no room for advancement in this company. I say almost because there are a few people that do get promoted, however about 90% of hires are external. In the rare case someone DOES get promoted, it is usually not because of experience or skills but politics. Personality is more valuable than workmanship here. - My previous point is only valid when Iron Mountain actually keeps the job position when an employee leaves. It is becoming the trend over the last few years to dissolve the job position when someone leaves and divide the work load between the surrounding workers. -They have been trying to "trim the fat" from the entire company the last few years. This has resulted in the amount of workers decreasing to the point were it is getting difficult to complete all the work they want us to do. - The leadership team has downright comical ideas on how to increase profits. All they could come up with was buy more companies or make all our employees do more work for the same amount of pay. They have gotten lucky because covid has made rising prices profitable for Iron Mountain and other companies. -Iron Mountain absolutely refuses to listen to criticism or any negative feedback. If a conversation or email has any of this in it, the person will completely ignore you. Instead, they keep providing lip service and plan to do this for the foreseeable future. Be prepared to hear "best in class", "industry leading", and other positive phrases repeatedly without any proof. Want to talk to someone about low pay? Why Iron Mountain has competitive pay that is industry leading! No it does not. Stop being delusional. The higher up you go in Iron Mountain, they more ridiculous the lip service is. -Their entire middle management is full of some of the worst employees I have ever seen. Brown nosing, laziness, favoritism, and incompetence run rampant in this part of the company. I have yet to meet any individual in middle management that can lead effectively. Most of the time the front line workers have had to cover for them. -There is a huge disparity between corporate and front line. Nobody in corporate seems to notice this but it is very apparent to the front line workers. 1. Front line workers receive no bonuses while corporate does. 2. Only front like workers had their pay cut during covid. All managers, salaried employees, and executives received full pay. TOTALLY FAIR RIGHT? 3. Corporate employees have the option to work from home while front line workers do not. 4. Home/work balance only applies to corporate, front line workers are expected to be on call 24/7 in case of emergencies. 5. Front line workers are required to hit insanely high quotes while corporate sit in meetings all day. 6. Corporate employees get to travel and go to retreats abroad on the companies dime. -As per above, lower level employees are required to meet quotes every day. These are incredibly difficult to hit for most employees. In some buildings, they require you to be practically running the entire shift. This is just the beginning, most managers want you to go above and beyond. Why? The bonus of higher level employees is based off of revenue, which is directly related to how high the numbers are that the front line generate. -The buildings front line employees work in do not have air condition or heat. Expect to work in extreme heat or cold depending on where you live. - The company is trying really hard for zero injuries. They keep lecturing about safety all the time and it is really annoying. This is a completely unrealistic goal because the front line has to work in a very physical environment. Being required to move a few hundred boxes a day is going to take a toll on a persons body. Nothing you do will stop the wear and tear. -The culture at Iron Mountain seems more like a cult. They are constantly creating new phrases and sayings that are repeated daily by management. We have to watch new videos, training, and various other things to help reinforce the culture they want to create. The expectation is to go above and beyond for no real reason except that we love working at Iron Mountain. -People at Iron Mountain seem to have an inflated ego. Playing the blame game is pretty common. - For any position in this company, the pay is lower than what other companies will offer. If you happen to work in one of the hourly jobs at Iron Mountain, you will probably be living paycheck to paycheck. Do not expect to be able to afford expensive things like cars, houses, and vacations without a significant other. You cannot ask for a raise, they are only given on a set date. Even then, the raises are a complete and utter insult. On average, it is a couple of dimes, if you are lucky. I mean cents, not dollars here. That is not even close to covering the cost of inflation. -Because of the low pay and benefits, Iron Mountain has a really hard time attracting young and talented employees. Outside of the corporate offices, it is difficult to find someone with a college degree. It is probably even harder to find someone under the age of 30. This is a boomer company. -You cannot start at Iron Mountain and build a career. You are required to have all necessary skills and experience prior to starting your position at Iron Mountain. Throughout your term here, you will not gain anything valuable that you can leverage to get a higher position here or somewhere else. You most likely will be doing some boring and repetitive task. -You can be fired at any moment. Job security is not a thing here. You will hear, "If you don't like it, leave" and will be constantly told this by management. Welcome to the machine, cog.

title: Great Company
pros: Benefits and pay is excellent. Very aggressive in growth strategy, and very, very customer focused then operationally and financial focused. They had a restructure in company organization with SEC recently which gave them a lot of tax benefits. Culture is good, but operations are spread out in densely in markets, requiring leadership to stay on the move to manager resources.
cons: I really didn't see any Con's with them.

title: Underpay staff
pros: Flexibility to work from home and flexible work hours were a plus. Travel opportunities and a lot of different lines of business. Decent benefits but not outstanding.
cons: Completely undervalue their employees. Could have specifically been that particular management but they take advantage of your working time and expect you to be responsive and available no matter the time or day. Not much opportunity for growth. Top heavy for sure.

title: 25 Years at Iron Mountain
pros: The people are great. I have built strong relationships with co-workers that feel like family. Iron Mountain cares about its employees. I have had many opportunities for advancement and new roles.
cons: The pay could be better. Or atleast the bonuses. You stop receiving incentives for longevity after 21 years (extra vacation/additional annual bonus..ect). Group meetings/training for managers would also be inspiring.

title: Positive environment to work in!
pros: IRM is a great company to work for. Overall the interactions with other employees, managers and executives have been very positive. The company does a good job communicating their goals and values. The team I work with is very positive, supportive and hard working.
cons: In some cases internal processes are not well defined and understanding the corporate structure can be a mystery.

title: Be wary of Favortisim
pros: Excellent opportunity to teach myself a new industry.
cons: Senior Management promotes from within based on how much they like you rather than if you can do the job. Lack of training (I had to figure out how to do my job on my own) and ultimately they would rather stand behind a wrong decision then admit they were wrong.

title: Very political, watch your back
pros: Co-workers were a good group. Great location in downtown Boston
cons: Company is on the way down so management is thinning the herd. Never know when you're next on the chopping block. Everyone is keeping their head down, can't take chances.

title: Pay was great, Management trickery prevailed
pros: Telecomuting was an option, Gym falcilites (new), not much more than that.
cons: No formal training (go home and snuggle up with a pdf) , Boston management show a professional front, but permeate Dr Hyde, Mr. Jeckle management style. Failure to communicate effectively ... plausible deniability The management appears to make decisions and achieve poor results, then fix then and pat themselves for a good job.... They shine away from how they got to the problem the first place....

title: Iron Mountain Digital - Archipelago of companies rather than a continent
pros: Good people to collaborate with. Gained experience with different solutions. Cloud solutions with very physically secure data centers. Credibility with IT departments for its technical solutions.
cons: Solutions from acquired companies not integrated or consolidated together. Different groups and niches with different perspectives. Was better working for Iron Mountain Digital before its spin-off of unit to Autonomy.

title: Loved my job until position eliminated
pros: Local management was terriffic. Good benefits and incentive programs.
cons: The corporate programs which treated managers and supervisors all as if they were entry level employees. Micromanaged the employee appreciation process.

title: Disgusted!
pros: Great team players in the company, challenging decent pay and benefits.
cons: Horrible management. GM totally clueless let people go and do not replace them. More work and less people all the time. Definitely do not value their employees or care about their opinions. Used to be a great place to work once upon a time.

title: I prepped and scanned documents and old files for corporation to incorporate their files in an online filing system.
pros: Job was easy and fun and interesting, and the supervisor was very funny and fun to work with.
cons: No challeneges sometimes you had to fast because of deadlines and accuracies was a given.

title: Director
pros: Iron Mountain attracts good dedicated people to the organization.
cons: Iron Mountain is not a friendly environment for women and minorities to rise through the ranks. And when women and minorities make it past the glass ceiling, their is no monitoring of the Company's VP leader's disbursement of salary, raises and stock options awards which results in a very uneven pay scale.

title: Fantastic atmosphere, great place to work!
pros: A very awesome culture, with nice people and great common areas Organized and clean operations A fun place to go to work everyday
cons: Senior execs sometimes brought in from other companies instead of grown from within Sometimes communication between departments was slow

title: Do not recommend Iron Mountain
pros: Great teammates; really good work; when CEO hired, looked promising. Good pay.
cons: Churns people in and out constantly. Unfortunately, CEO cares about shareholders, not employees. Layoffs often. Work you to death.

title: TERRIBLE company
pros: They did buy supplies for the warehouse.
cons: Does not reward hard work. Promoted unsafe work environment . Unethical, management was never honest with us I was lied to on numerous occasions including the day I was let go. Worked for Recall for three yrs in May 2016 was purchased by Iron Mountain. Was laid off June 2017. After our warehouse signed up to join union. Not enough to do was the reason given, only 3 employees in the warehouse. Kept one employee replaced rest with temps.

title: Best job I've had yet.
pros: Coworkers will grow on you, Great management, consistent work and hours, friendly HR, Relaxed atmosphere, great for young people as you can learn alot and they will help pay for school.
cons: Layoffs can be sudden and merciless.

title: Don’t work for iron mountain
pros: You are able to work overtime
cons: - Out of 261 working days not to include the holidays you don’t get off or the weekend that you work You are only allowed 7 occurrences in a year. Iron mountain charges you an occurrence for calling in sick and you are actually sick, for arriving to work late due to an accident that you can’t control, for clocking in late @7:15 and work starts at 7:15 mind you the company gives you 10 min, but your boss doesn’t. They question your call in if your sick then text you when your sick to ask if you’re coming to work the next day. If you work as a driver they give you anywhere between 25-32 or more routes and then will add on a route that another driver failed or rather didn’t do instead of making them go back and do it... You can ask for leave and they can give it, but also take it back after approval or just tell you no because there are already 2 ppl off even though there are 15 or more guys working. It’s alll about their numbers and the $$$ they can get to fill their pockets. Oh and on the bonuses you get them every three months but it’s on the same check as your pay so your extra taxed. So if the bonus was 500.00 you’ll get somewhere close to 300.00 it that. Mind you the bonuses is based off of your superior performance. Oh and don’t have a death in the family out of town and you can get up to 5 days bereavement.. They will give you 2 and you use your time for the rest. Pay more and stop these 10 cent raises . This isn’t the 1/2 of the stuff they do.. It’s pretty on the outside, but the inside is a mess..

title: Data Entry
pros: Calm environment, not taxing in project work or regular keying
cons: The downsides are: Raises once a year! No advancement opportunity. Supervisors give no credit or advice to an employee. They ignore everyone.

title: Great Place to Work - Long Career
pros: Smart and caring people who are passionate about the company. Great environment of collaboration and innovation. CEO has a strong vision and does a great job communicating to the wider organization. Opportunity to be entrepreneurial within an established industry leader.
cons: Sometimes people care too much, and become overly vested in their work.

title: Overwhelming Expectations
pros: Wonderful people, everyone is very helpful
cons: Huge learning curve for complicated product and services offering. Way to much administrative work for sales role. Vacation benefits don't start acruing until you've been there 6 months.

title: Very political
pros: IM is a company with potential but it has never realized its potential. It has a lot of resources available.
cons: It is a very political comany that seems to reward "yes" people. IM is full of good managers but no leaders.

title: A roller coaster
pros: At the time that I worked the compensation plan was great. People were happy and getting a long well.
cons: After the restructured the compensation plan people started to leave and dislike each other.

title: Not impressed
pros: Work life balance is decent.
cons: Current Supervisors and Coordinators are terrible. They are all friends and employees can't say anything for fear of losing their jobs. There is no room for advancement, they keep taking jobs away and employees are stuck where they are currently.

title: Outstanding
pros: Great benefits, outstanding opurtunities for growth (upper management). If one is fortunate enough to have a great upper management team, the sky is the limit.
cons: Not good personnel matches on key upper management positions can prevent one from achieving their fullest potential.

title: Overall, I was treated very well.
pros: No shortage of work. Always busy. They have good medical, dental, vision, vacation, sick leave, 401k. Most of the people I worked with were really knowledgeable about things.
cons: There were some really long days. Typically I worked about 55 hours per week. The way their bonus program works could be changed.

title: They don't care about the little people.
pros: Air conditioning during the hot summer.
cons: Raises are ridiculous. They also like to dangle carrots that there will be promotions and more money, and it doesn't happen.

title: This company sucks for the little man
pros: - Not many. - Set schedule at best. - No micro management
cons: - No room for growth career wise - slave pay for repetitive labor - Ergonomics completely ignored in warehouse safety - Just a boring job - No labeling of warehouse areas. Difficult to navigate. - No actual training at all

title: Overall A Decent Company To Work For
pros: Not a great deal of turn over. Immediate supervisors and co-workers have always been really great to work with.
cons: Investors and those that sit on Wall Street seem to have become a bit to greedy.

title: Data Entry Specialist
pros: The schedule was nice, 4:45-1:15
cons: There is favoritism, if you aren't Buddy buddy with a supervisor or manager, forget it. Oh, and speaking up for noting things that slows down production, nope.

title: Steer Clear
pros: The workers on the floor or out in the field are team players for the most part.
cons: The pay scale is horrible and is now no longer payed out by performance. You are a drone to this company and nothing more. You will receive absolutely no reward for hard work and will not receive any merrit just more work! You are treated well until you say no or have a problem with the way the boss dictates things need to be set.

title: A company stuck in the past
pros: Good quality of life Smart people
cons: Unable to shift out of the legacy business of paper storage No stomach for innovation

title: Glad it's over
pros: The company has great name recognition for your resume. It is a good stepping stone to other potential employment opportunities.
cons: Too much nepotism and cronyism is promotions. Many people in the highest positions have no idea what they are actually supposed to be doing, and the rest of the staff is covering for them. You will likely not have a different title than the one you get when you are first hired.

title: Sales Rep.
pros: Great group of people to work with!
cons: At the time I was there the training dept. was not the best, large turn over. They were still in the stage of development at the time and I'm sure all is in place now.

title: Accounting/Finance
pros: The pay and benefits were a little below average, but the work/life balance was much better than at companies of equal size. The work was steady and the business didn't change much, so the environment was steady and mostly calm
cons: Without many special projects or new areas of the business to explore, the career path is somewhat capped with limited growth potential.

pros: Great place to work. Learning environment that makes room for creative thinking when approaching a opportunity. Lots of focus on the employee experience that makes for a better customer experience
cons: The companies core business is in retreat. Lots of reorganization going on. Several large reductions in work force lately. next big challenge will be to fold in new acquisition.

title: Document custodian formerly BNY Mellon Bought by Iron Mountain
pros: None at all they are jerks
cons: Their entire line of business

title: Run by a bunch of narrow minded white men
pros: There are a number of smart people working on strategy and trying to bet better shareholder value.
cons: Unfortunately, the core business is run by a bunch of narrow-minded, old boy network white men where the group holds favorites

title: Horrible
pros: Great pay is the only pro.
cons: Management is horrible and seems that supervisors are always being fired and drivers keep quiting. If upper management needs someone to cut they will roll the dice and fire you in a heart beat. Also manager changes on a drop of a dime.

title: Seize the Opportunities
pros: Enormous opportunities for career growth if you are adaptable and willing to take on challenges and stretch yourself; Strong leaders who support their employees; people who live the corporate values everyday; commitment to diversity and inclusion;
cons: Lots of change and you need to be flexible and adaptable which may not be for everyone;

title: Still a great place to work
pros: I've been at the Mountain for 20 years and have seen lots of change in that time and would still recommend this as a great place to work! Great leadership, benefits and competitive pay, as well as, pride in what we do and how we make an impact on the world.
cons: I can't think of anything.

title: Problems within management
pros: Good employees to work with. Decent benifits
cons: I can't speak for the other braches around the world so i will just talk about management in the elk grove and sacramento locations. At first i enjoyed working for the company. After about a year no one seem to care anymore, it was just another paycheck to them.The morale of the employees is at a all time low and management dont seem to care because issues were brought up on dozen of occassions, but nothing was done. Their only concern was to make the numbers so they can get a nice bonus every quarter. All that was done was employees getting terminated for speaking up. By far in the Sacramento and Elk Grove branch, they have the worst management team i ever work for. Besides the constant harrassment of management as well as the lies, employees are faced with favoritism. There is a circle within the company and if you are not within that circle you are basically screwed. Employees have lost their jobs from following what their superiors told them to do. I lost count how many time management have altered documents to make themselve look good. All it cost was an employee to lose his or her job. Another thing i honestly do not understand how some people got into their positions because these individuals seem to lack skills in their department. I guess the saying is true "Do as i say and not as i do" is the real motto of the company. There is no integrity within management, they are only concern about the well being and are willing to do anything for their own benifits. The company itself is a good company, just a few individuals in certain key positions that are destroying Iron Mountain.

title: If you like making just enough to get by... then work here
pros: I do love the benefits here
cons: When it comes time for a raise they use presents, like 1 percent of you current salary. That's what I got after a year of work... 1 percent increase.

title: Need leadership training program, but stable future
pros: Good new hire training program; secure company with stable future
cons: Need both technical and soft skills to excel at role (may not be clearly communicated in job postings); poor frontline leadership with lack of training in providing feedback and coaching to employees

title: Stable Company
pros: For the most part the job is stable and there is consistent workload. Workload is manageable and goals are attainable.
cons: Not a lot of room for growth. Recognition is broadly based, so not a lot of individual bonuses for exceeding the overall group.

title: Sales Training
pros: Iron Mountain offers a very extensive, robust training program for their sales teams. Our teams also get all the resources they need to be successful (CRM, prospecting tools, etc.).
cons: The new hire goes through the training courses at their convenience and timeline. You need to have that self discipline to go through the course in the time expected in order to be truly successful.

pros: None, if you're a middle aged white man, the sky is the limit. I hope someone has the courage one day to litigate this company for their discriminatory practices promoting women.
cons: I worked for this company for 7 years. What a waste of my life. Now when I apply to anything and try to use anyone from that company as a professional reference, it's against company policy for them to give references. Also if you work here please stop letting this company talk you out of voting in favor of a union.

title: Inside sales
pros: Great people to work along side. Decent money. Nice location and cafeteria.
cons: New vp is changing the culture. No one feels secure. Top management has been fired. Without explanation and yet he doesn’t understand why we feel upset or don’t trust his methods. More concerned about process than people.

title: Account Manager
pros: Most people are great to work with once you find the right contacts and resources.
cons: There are multiple members of upper management that have reached “their level of incompetency”. If you are not familiar with this term please refer to “The Peter Principle: Why Things Always Go Wrong” By (author) Laurence J. Peter, By (author) Raymond Hull. Also, the company is very sales driven and the customer relationships are falling by the wayside.

title: Great job to work at, learn and grow with good opportunities for promotions within the company.
pros: There is great opportunities to improve personal / business growth and develop leadership skills in the company, with good opportunity for promotions in almost every position...if you are willing to put in the work for them. Good benefits for employees.
cons: Health benefits costs rises every year with more out of pocket pay for employees

title: There are better jobs!!! Keep looking!
pros: It's a job...you come to work 8 hours a day 5 days a week and you take home a check every two weeks. There is a ton of volunteer hours if that is something you are into. It can be an easy job.
cons: The management is horrible! I can't speak for the whole company, but at our location communication is definitely something they lack! Micromanagement! It is all about the numbers, good for the company, exasperating for the employees. Expectations of employees to follow procedures and guidelines when they themselves do not!

title: It's ok. Culture is a little boring. They lay people off a lot.
pros: No drama. Nice people. Cafe serves good food. Nice office.
cons: They lay people off at the drop of a hat. A few months later, they rehire for the same role.

title: Run far away!!
pros: I cannot think of any. As a former Recall employee where you were treated with respect, you will see none of that with Iron Mountain.
cons: Pay is horrible, IM tracks your movement down to the minute all day every day. As an example, if you stop for gas in vehicle, you have exactly 4 minutes to complete the task. If not, you will hear about it. If there is road construction, you will need to write down exactly how many minutes it took you.

title: Truck Driver
pros: Equipment is up to date and that's it.
cons: The pay is incredibly low for the amount of work we put in. The most difficult part is dealing with hypocritical management that has no experience in the industry at all. The benefits don't measure up to the hard work of a driver instead of rewarding the driver they pile more work on you. The raises are below average and don't equal to the performance you make on the job.

title: Used to be a great company

title: Business Analyst

title: review of working at Iron Mountain:
pros: A typical day involves handling physical documents or digital data, focusing on accuracy and security for client requests like storage, retrieval, or shredding. You learn valuable skills in logistics, data management, and security protocols, understanding how businesses manage information. Management varies but is generally process-driven, with a clear hierarchy. The workplace culture emphasizes stability, security, and reliability, often fostering teamwork in operations. The hardest part can be the physical demands and the pressure of maintaining accuracy with large volumes of sensitive information under strict deadlines. The most enjoyable aspect is the satisfaction of providing essential, secure services that help businesses operate smoothly, along with the company's stability and team collaboration.

title: AVOID
pros: A few good people were the only thing that made it bearable at times. Slightly more than minimum wage.
cons: Working here was an incredibly draining and damaging experience. The culture was toxic from the top down, with staff treated more like disposable tools than people. Management frequently resorted to bullying tactic, shouting, name-calling, and public humiliation were disturbingly common. This created a tense and hostile environment. One of the most destabilising aspects was the unpredictability of management. One day they would be openly aggressive and rude; the next they'd act as if nothing had happened. Behind closed doors, managers regularly criticised both staff and each other, fostering mistrust and tension across the team. Double standards were everywhere. Managers could take 45 minute vape breaks without issue, while other employees were micromanaged or disciplined for minor mistakes. Favouritism was common: some staff were treated extremely leniently, while others were dismissed without warning. The job itself lacked challenge or progression. Instructions were inconsistent and deadlines unrealistic. Training was minimal and poorly structured, often left in the hands of inexperienced staff. The general disorganisation showed how little the company invested in its people. The working environment was filthy and dusty. I developed health issues as a direct result, and I’m certain I wasn’t the only one. Despite this, there was no visible effort to improve health and safety standards. There was consistently high turnover, with the company heavily reliant on agency staff to fill roles. This instability reflected wider problems in the working environment. The pay was £13 per hour, but given the conditions, it didn’t feel like fair compensation. Holiday requests were routinely ignored or refused, reinforcing the sense that staff were not valued. This job wasn’t worth the stress, damage, or effort. I’m just glad I got out, and I wouldn’t recommend it to anyone!!!

title: A deeply disappointing experience – toxic culture and lack of professionalism
pros: Hardly I found any pros.
cons: My experience at Iron Mountain has been overwhelmingly negative. The work culture is toxic, with little to no appreciation for effort or collaboration. Instead of fostering teamwork, there is a prevailing blame culture where individuals are quick to point fingers rather than work together to solve problems. I’ve worked in various organization throughout my career, but I’ve never encountered an environment so hostile and unsupportive. Constructive feedback is rare, and recognition is virtually nonexistent. Sadly, it often feels like some individuals are more interested in protecting their own positions than helping others succeed. If you're considering a role here, I strongly advise you to do your due diligence and think carefully. A toxic work environment not only affects your professional growth but can also take a toll on your mental and emotional well-being.

title: Avoid working here
pros: There are no positives from my experience
cons: Lack of training, lack of support from line manager, lack of integrating into the team. Given a training document to “self train”, document extremely confusing for a new starter. Discussed at interview about working US hours for at least 2 months. No access during the first week, shadow training the second week and then in the third week told to work UK hours and told to rely on the training document. Time zone differences made it extremely difficult to get support. Even when support was sought, told to refer back to the training document or asked “what do you think is the issue”. A very frustrating and difficult experience. Lack of contracts and quotes coming in also made learning the role difficult. Some days I was only allocated one quote to work on. Also told to ask all questions via the chat system, Manager regularly referred to the team for several queries as she often did not know the answer. Also given some out of date training information which was I was not aware of until errors were made because the information in the training was wrong. Due to Bank Holidays and 2 days holiday, I was out of the office for a week, first week no access, second week shadowing someone, 3rd week on UK time with no support until 5 hrs later - so a month in total where no real training was given. For 3.5 weeks of the remaining 2 months, Manager did not speak to me or touch base with me, no 121 correspondence at. Told at 3 month review that I was not picking up the role and that the errors I made were avoidable had I referred to the training document correctly and that I was not progressing. I would have contested but the environment was not pleasant one at all and I was happy to have left. I have only written this review to warn people is how isolated and unsupported this role is.

title: Great Place to work, benefits.
pros: Iron Mountain has always tried to give you what you need to succeed, whether it is training on something like the power pallet jack, or a pair of gloves, whatever you need that will help you be safe. They have good benefits and take safety very seriously. Often my building will host bbqs, that is if our district is doing well. Internal job postings and relocation assistance. When I went part time so I could attend school full time they were very accommodating, putting me on a different shift with a different job, but keeping my pay rate. Discipline is quite different from other jobs I've worked. Instead of an attitude of, "you did this, don't let this happen again" it is, "why did this happen, what can we, you and management, do to make sure you or others don't do the same thing."
cons: Sometimes other teams like warehouse staff will be using the equipment you need, certain items that you need on your truck for the day may get borrowed and not returned leaving you wasting time trying to locate it. Everything you do is tracked, as in, time you spent doing this work and doing that work. Sometimes things you run into during the day can slow you down and affect you reaching your target. Some things are hard to account for and you must be proactive in communicating all issues otherwise all management will see is the target not being hit. Room to advance but only if the position opens up which isn't too often.

title: When hired, I was ecstatic and believed I was working for a great company. Not so much.
pros: Iron Mountain offers a wonderful benefits package and is very flexible with allowing time off. The people you work with are very pleasant and hardworking.
cons: Iron Mountain has experienced exponential growth as a result of ill planned acquisitions. They failed to be proactive in updating systems to accomodate all the growth. Their IT - Finance, Procurement, HRIS (etc) systems are extremely dissapointing and, in an effort to save money, let go of most of their IT professionals and outsourced to India. Promises made to department projects are put on hold while this transition is happening and no status updates are communicated. Unfortunately, there is very little advancement opportunities. When there is an opportunity, you must be a favorite (aka Yes person). Recruiters, mostly contractors, do not seem to pay attention to talent given their lack of response to employee referrals. There is very much a lack of communication between departments that truly need to communicate in order to be successful. it seems everyone works in boxes and has no idea what others are doing - when they should. There would be so much more synergy and work getting done.

title: The Pros do not outweigh the Cons
pros: do not outweigh the
cons: Where to begin...I have worked at Iron Mountain for 3 years. During that time I have seen many incompetent people be promoted, while high performers are either laid off or given no opportunity for growth or career enhancment. Sure, they will give you more work and more responsibility, but don't expect to be paid for it. The company touts that they "Pay for Performance", but that couldn't be farther from the truth. Unless you are a "favorite" to senior management (VP+), you will never be paid what the industry says you should. It is truly dispicable that a company so large can be so corrupt. Managers are clearly hired without professional references being checked. There is an unacceptable population of managers who have no employee development skills. They are out for themselves, and are only concerned with keeping their job and looking good to management. Additionally, too many times I have seen the company hire an external person for a position, rather than grooming and developing an internal high performer. Executive-level management is a "good old boys" environment. Until that changes, this company will continue to be an unfair and frustrating working environment.

title: Time to move on
pros: Guaranteed paycheck. Great support from immediate supervisors. My department was a great team to work with. Immediate management understood family needs, and made sure shift coverage was available when needed.
cons: Absolutely no growth for lower employees, promotions are based on the buddy system. Senior management had made promises (for 2 yrs) to cross train employees/contractors for employment growth, and failed miserably. Iron Mountain brought in VPs with experience in transferring jobs over seas, and with the intent to send IT positions over seas. Now Iron Mountain is in the process of training another country to do what we have been doing for years. Iron Mountain wants to be recognized as a Global Company, unfortunately at the expense of their North American employees. Iron Mountain has also created multiple customer service departments to assist their costumers, unfortunately, those teams have no idea what they are suppose to do, nor what the other teams do, and forward all customers to the IT departments.

title: It's very repetitive, and sooooo boring!
pros: It's a paycheck (somewhat). It's a stable company (for now) so as long as you show up and get your "actions per hour", you will have a job. Benefits are OK, and they offer tuition reimbursement. Co-workers are friendly.
cons: Upper management is way over-paid and the employees that do the slave labor are way under-paid. It's the most dead-end job I have ever had (I've had a lot of jobs). It's definitely a job and not a career path. A lot of the boxes we keep the customers material in are falling apart. Re-boxing is considered something you do only when there is nothing left to do. Cleaning has also been obsolete because it's not considered an action. They have put a real emphases on "actions per hour" and this has taken any fun there once was out of the company. If there is ever a job where somebody is a number, this is it. The company has what's called incentive compensation (I C) but that just gives the people making all the money more than they deserve. The ones that actually did the work get enough to maybe fill up their gas tank.

title: Corporate World
pros: Great people and free coffee.
cons: As in any Corporate Company, the non stop changes are something to either to get used to it or move on. The company is metrics driven and is pushing for the ultimate results at the bottom line with a very weak sales & new business focus. Everything that could be outsourced was and it definitely impacts performance of many departments. High reliability on temp force has shown to be a challenge as well. The decision making process in development of structures, improvement to business line and technology is something to wonder about. Too many delays, and lack of interest and focus makes this company a very hectic and unorganized place to work in. Too many people leave and more are given a package in an effort to squeeze a penny. Depending on department it is either over busy and employees are driven to intense overload of work for long periods of time or under performing thus creating an attitude of everlasting stagnancy. Lack of direction and clear expectations as well as poor leadership and management style contributes to overall dissatisfaction, stress and unnecessary fear. It used to be a good place to work at but as the time goes on, it lost its appeal.

Transformation would not have happened then. 800 life are affected because of you!!! IRM Boston Mgmt - IRM business is unique and is a market leader. But no one knows what they are trying to achieve operationally in IT in the long run. They first started off India operations with a service company and then realised captive model works better and started IMS. Fast forward 5 years the head count grew from 35 to a whopping 800 people working on almost all technology streams. Suddenly they come up with a transformation project and outsource it to a service company.. IMS mgmt never understands the pulse of boston bosses. A great organization crashes down like a house of playing cards.

title: Marching towards irrelevance
pros: Iron Mountain has had successful run over the past fifteen years. Most of the employees are sincere and well intentioned.
cons: Not a performance culture. In addition, management has been out of sorts for the past several years and unable to respond to the declining economy and the fundamental changes in the core business. With the recent investor action (firing of a lackluster CEO) the company has doubled down on its paper storage business and it's starving off every other business line even as management continues to insist that they are forward thinking and want to think beyond "the box." Major talent drain over the past few months and many more good people about to walk out of the door.

title: Iron Mounta, gearing towards an Employee's Choice goal.
pros: The best reasons for working for Iron Mountain is the fact that CANDOR is a very improtant Core Value. Overall, Candor can be expressed upward or downward and is always meant to be a constructive and continuing educational environment. Iron Mountain prides itself in also offering a very competitive benefits package including medical, dental vision and FSA Medical/Dependent care. They offer Employee Assistance as well as international Travel insurance, short term and long term disability and career development opportunities. Overall, this company is a great place to work with very competitive benefits. Great leadership support and work ethic of all employees due to outstanding support from all departments.
cons: Change Management. Overall, Iron Mountain is moving towards a Performance Driven culture that will rate employees based on a Pay for Performance scale. A large partof the employee population has consisted of acquisitions of several competitors companies that has led to a bleeding cultural effect as we move towards a new frontier. Communication vehicles are not always as revolving and streamlined as you would expect from a billion dollar organization but this has gotten better with the implementation of a new Human Resources team geared in advocating a better "partnership" with frontline employees.
