title: Business Development
pros: Unfortunately what used to be a good company to work for is no longer true. Company change to a REIT meant a complete change of direction and the individual is no longer respected. Everything is based on how costs can be cut, how much work they can add to existing staff, getting rid of managers and putting undue pressure on supervisors, charging the customer for absolutely everything eg. Tapes... if a client requests a new label be printed, Iron Mountain charge for storage of that tape immediately even though the tape may not physically come into storage for weeks / months. Upper management kept that quiet and Customer Service found out by having to deal with a customer complaint about charges they were not expecting. Amazing talent let go without a second thought. Non performing amateurs retained. VP's keeping non performing managers out of favoritism and letting the hard working staff go (because these are the people who speak up and that is frowned upon).
cons: Apart from the above!! It's driven to keep investors happy, no longer a long term work place. They have taken the heart and soul out of the company. Call centers closed in the US and Canada and replaced with ones in India and the Philippines. So many customer complaints about this and reduced customer care.

title: Good
pros: Work environment was not bad
cons: Salary is not good as i expected

title: Offshore/India centre is a cheap sweat shop run by petty management
pros: > Good business model for global operations, and some strategic/lucky investments in the past 75 years have paid off well
cons: > Cheap place - these guys call you for an in-person interview to Bangalore, and don't even reimburse the ticket. Pathetic HR won't respond to mails > They call an AVP/top-consulting, IIT and IIM grad with 13 years of industry-wide experience, and ask to be a project manager, 5 levels below the India IT head, who is a VP, and then when questioned on the move, in complete irony, ask what's the big deal in a designation. Then why create so many levels when you are interviewing to have someone report to the VP - yet another hierarchical officious organization fit for 40+ people to sit and twiddle thumbs > Bad offshoring plans in India - most MNCs that setup shop in India seem to send their worst bureaucratic and ancient feudal-minded people, that believe we still in a colonial age and can get work done by cracking a whip

title: We do not follow our own core values--and employees and customers suffer for it.
pros: Great employees on the team, the customers are, for the most part, wonderful to work with, comfortable work environment, pay is okay with the exception of the bonus plan--which could use great improvement in its implementation.
cons: Decisions are made by upper management that greatly impact employees and customers in a negative way due to the fact that the decision-makers are clueless as to what their decisions will mean. As a front customer-facing employee, I find myself apologizing for these decisions. Deep cuts in staff have made it difficult at best to respond to customers in a timely manner. Annual surveys are misunderstood by upper management. Local management can't or won't tell HQ that when they (HQ) make bad decisions. Employees and customers then suffer due to the negative impact of these decisions.

title: A company who has no compassion for ground staff who works hard for the company during tiring times.
pros: Staff compensation and benefits scheme built up by previous company before the acquisition in 2016. If you are a part of the Management Team, then you are in luck! During the past few years, the Management Team have been going for monthly dinner and drinks and annual vacation even though the company were told that we are not making enough.
cons: Retrenching staff in order to boost up the profits without a care about how the lean workforce will affect the health and productivity rate of ground staff who is already struggling. This in turns affects customers who have to endure with slow/late/no-show service, The company culture is advocating ' you don't have to work hard, you just need to make your boss happy' to be a 'privilege group' of the company.

title: Good to work for short term personal growth - stone age management policies will drive you nuts.
pros: Excellent opportunities to deal with a wide variety of customers/clients. If you are looking to enhance your client portfolio this is the company to work for. Iron Mountain has a list of top tier clients that you will have access to regardless of what you're doing there. My advice for anyone considering a role at Iron Mountain is to get in and get out. Don't stay there for more than 4 years maximum.
cons: Communication both inside and outside the company is extremely poor. Iron Mountain has not gotten up to speed internally with the latest technology/business trends. A large chunk of the management layer within various groups of Iron Mountain needs to be reorganized or removed all together. Depending on what you're doing - you will not get an opportunity for promotion. Get the idea that you will promoted after working hard/long hours at IM out of your head quickly. Management has very strange/awkward promotion policies. This is not a company where you will rise up the corporate ladder so to speak.

title: Iron Mountain is not as great as it could be.
pros: Lots of great people work at the company from all kinds of disciplines and backgrounds.
cons: A huge blame culture existed during my tenure. It was not "one strike and you are out " - but it was pretty close. Middle managers were actively engaged in protecting their own positions and that of their loyal subjects at the expense of up and coming star performers, who were culled during the opportunity arising from recent economic downturn. The company has too many poorly qualified "up through the ranks managers" who are seriously deficient in the required levels of motivational, developmental, interpersonal and basic management skills required by todays global economy.

title: Not Good, and getting worse by the minute
pros: The best part of my job is the people that I work with every day on a local level. I also really care about and like my customers, have great relationships with them.
cons: It's all about metrics. The true focus on the customer and the customers' experience is getting weaker by the day. Internal cost-cutting is getting to the point of ridiculous, especially in light of the huge bonuses/stock options senior leadership get, AND the fact that this company seems to like to pay sales reps for deals they weren't even a part of. If you want an easy sales position, where you don't have to cold call, you don't really have to SELL anything, and you get paid for the work that others do, then this is the place to be!

title: Lack of communication
pros: Clean work environment and excellent co-workers
cons: Supervisors lacking in area's such as following company rules, very disorganized and do not like an employee thinking for themselves. Very "Stepford Wives" like. Breaks and lunches at a certain time, unless it is in the supervisor's best interest that you wait and hour before taking them. You get lectured on State mandated times for these, but they will bend if they want you to complete a task, not if you want to take a later break/lunch. Communication not allowed amongst employee's, (how weird is that?). Poorly trained supervisor's, if you work in a department you should know EVERY aspect of it, not just what you are comfortable with.

title: Disgusting company! Incompetent managent. Constant redundancies and fear culture
pros: If you love politics, a manage by fear culture and people that don't take responsibility this is your perfect place. You spend your whole career wondering if you will be next in their "cost cutting" or "improved EBITDA" redundancy rounds
cons: tant redundancies and fear culture

title: Wouldn't go back
pros: Great brand, great sales team in Mid Market during my time. Loads of other great folks the business.
cons: Management of Mid market sales was trapped in 1970's micro management style with no insight or vision, All been brought in from rentagenericsalesmanagers.com. Many had recently moved Jim Henson companies bringing with them a distinct style of management. Senior Management included carousel of MD's, each with the their idea how to make things work. We had 5 in 9 years, better chances being a football manager. This produced the instability of constant restructuring and jostling for power. Latterly management done everything but listen to the frontline troops and very few of their fixes worked. They operated a distinct closed door policy with some of the SLT imbuing themselves with the status of business Gods and living in suitably constructed ivory towers. IM have lost focus and are losing customers by the hundreds.

title: Stable work environment with lots of good co-workers
pros: The people at Iron Mountain are great. There are very few teamwork based issues. The work / life balance is fairly well managed and the benefits have multiple options to fit family and budget.
cons: At least at my location, promotions almost never occur. The local management is swarmed with activities throughout the year, so it seems they put career development on the back burner for their employees.

title: Iron Mountain UK. Just a Job.
pros: Working hours suit me well. Can be flexible if and when needed. The people I work with are fantastic.
cons: Very top heavy company, seems like there is more management than staff. We've had staff leave in the last couple of years that have not been replaced so the few staff that we have in the warehouse have to bare the burden. As a result we can't always deliver our promises to the customers. Management doesn't like to listen to their workforce and often say "its tomorrows problem" There is no advancement to your career what so ever and the basic salary is poor compared to what is expected from you. Very few useful benefits. There is a blame culture. Companies "Core Values" often seem to be ignore/overlooked

title: Too big to care, too set in their ways to change.
pros: At the lowest levels, Iron Mountain is a fine place to work, management cares, etc. Time off is readily available and most mid-level and below managers are very flexible.
cons: Iron Mountain will keep talking up their "core values", but when the time comes to show Integrity, or Candor, they fall flat. Management chooses to be penny wise and pound foolish, attacking problems from the top down instead of seeking input from those closest to the problems. In past layoffs, the decisions were made without any consideration about how they would affect the business, other than the bottom line. Customers suffered, the employees left behind suffered, and it was an all-around unpleasant experience.

title: Not like it used to be
pros: Good pay, flexible hours, people I worked with were great.
cons: Iron Mountain used to be a great place to work until they got consumed with saving money. As a whole they did not feel the recession until years later, around 2010. After they started loosing customers, their investments weren't paying off and upper management was being fired, they got consumed by saving money. Lay off after lay off and then the ultimate......offshoring jobs to India. It's sad really. I used to love working for them but now you just sit around waiting to see if you are the next group to go.

title: If you are looking for a new employer you should keep looking beyond Iron Mountain.
pros: Plenty of room for advancement if you are a yes man. Great place to work if you like to work with a Senior Management staff in IT that is clueless.
cons: Horrible Management staff within IT. Morale is at it lowest point in a decade. TONS of jobs being sent off-shore. Lots of risk in day to day business operations. Candor no longer exists as it will get you on the fast track to the unemployment line.

title: Overall evaluation
pros: a lot of flexibility, managers with an open mind, benefits, work-life balance, cosy work environment
cons: small salaries not aligned with the market for entry to mid level employees, lack of learning programs for the same category, outdated IT systems at regional level which is ironically for this type of company

title: Bait and Switch
pros: Good Benefits Some glimmer of good business strategy
cons: Iron Mountain has the brand but struggles with execution. I find some of their decisions are knee-jerk and not well thought out. No synergy between sales and operations. Increases in fees sent in the mail to customers without any feedback from field sales. Yikes! I attended meetings where we were told the marching orders and future vision only to go back 6 months later and get a whole different set of direction. You have to be "in the boys club" to get heard. Frustrating, frustrating culture. From the outside it looks friendly and open but once you go to work there you find it is anything but open.

title: Could be so much better...
pros: Has some great products which could do really well in the market place The US team are really inspiring as they believe in Iron Mountain Flexible approach to working patterns Flexible approach to working locations including remote working Good work life balance HR team in Livingston are helpful and approachable Some newer senior managers are breaking the traditional 'old boys' network
cons: The UK and Western Europe teams don't believe in the US vision Some management behaviours are awful and are swept under the carpet If you don't fit in with the poor behaviours your career will end very quickly The senior HR team just don't care or are dismissive. The only one I could trust in years and confided in was removed The salaries and benefits don't really compare in the market, especially not in London Outdated technology and equipment means you are less effective Lack of marketing material hinders ability to sell Unstructured approach to change over the past few years has made the environment very difficult to work in Engagement is really poor

title: CFO feared by all and respected by none
pros: When these guys work out what they want to be when they grow up they would be awesome. Great financial model and backing to do what they need to do to dominate.
cons: Very poor UKSMT lead by inexperience and fear of the CFO who employs every undermining tactic they can to destroy careers, other teams and generally dodge any wrong doing through shouting louder than others. UKMD needs to stick to bed pans and patient meals which she is ultimately more suited for controlling.

title: Effort and Drive can breed opportunity
pros: There is a lot of opportunity for those willing to work hard and put in the time/effort. There are great training programs in-place that should be taken advantage of. The benefits are good and the ability to have a career that actually affords you some work/life balance definately holds intangible value
cons: There are quite a few software programs and redundant operating systems that one must master in order to sucessfully complete a days work. This isn't so much a negative as it is something that could stand to be streamlined. There were some sporadic lay-off's which tend to make things un-easy from time-to-time however, again as long as you hit your numbers and applied effort, there really isn't much to be concerned about.

title: A need for xonsistent leadership
pros: great peers, good benefits, potential is there to be a great company. the people work hard and are rewarded for their hard work.
cons: pay below scale, outsourcing work to India, unsure strategy/vision, concern about respect for existing digital employees, very slow decision making processes.

title: Going downhill - fast
pros: Historically a stable company. Relatively generous with compensation and benefits, although this declined some over the past few years.
cons: It pains me to write this, but this company has gotten worse and worse over the past few years. The focus has become less about the customer and more about internal politics. People are being promoted that are not well respected among the ranks - it's become more about "who you know" and who likes you, then whether or not you're actually doing a good job. I've seen some backstabbing firsthand.

title: Some good people ruined by a rotten culture
pros: Some good people who work hard to do the right thing, contribute to the company without asking for recognition. Salary not bad nor the commission scheme in years gone by. Decent sales managers on the whole and they are the market leader so incoming leads and existing client base is strong.
cons: Poor management from the top down. Loosing customers left right and centre due to poor customer service and service delivery. Makes future sales tougher and tougher as clients are becoming increasingly aware of the company's shortcomings. Top level management unaware of the rotten culture within the company (which they foster). Would love for them to listen to the people - just the once.

title: Love this company!
pros: Been here for over 6 months now and truly impressed with this company. Such a great atmosphere to work in, managers and superiors are encouraging and motivating. A lot to learn in the initial months but once you get the hang of things, it's a wonderful company to work for. Pay is more than competitive, benefits are great, work from home full time (a dream for me) and flexible schedule. They have the mentality of as long as you get your things done, it doesn't really matter what schedule you chose to work. Overall, highly recommended!
cons: Working remotely can be challenging at times to seek guidance. Being that this is a huge company, there are mega processes in place that need to be respected.

title: Was once a great company, now entering its twilight years?
pros: The company has a lot of smart people, most of who care about its future They are clearly the Market leader in their space Most people will tell you that they have a good work life balance Generally competitive pay and benefits
cons: Iron Mountain can be very political at times, in particular at the top. They aren't particularly good at growing talent. Most of the successful managers/executives are better at managing their own careers than their team's. The future will likely see lower growth and the company will become a nice, quiet, stable place to work, which is perfect for some people. Others may likely find it boring, though.

title: Autonomy in bucket loads, support at a minimum
pros: The autonomy to manage your team as you see fit. Annual salary increase Bonus scheme If you can stick at the boys club you will eventually be promoted.
cons: No support Difficult processes to negotiate No ownership Internal SLA’s are incredibly lengthy Archaic process American style attitude to people Managed to numbers and targets without concern for customer or staff.

title: "Better not to be here than having no choice later" - Regrets !
pros: - A wonderful business that I have come across. Interesting to know the way they function. Lots and lots of Data to manage. WOW ! Be here to know how it actually is. - New technologies are well encouraged but less incorporated. - Work from home option available depending on the experience, nature/type of work. - A place for those who want to do nothing much, but get paid huge. - A cool place for Female Employees. - A good company for people who has 10+ years of experience.
cons: - Not a place for hard working and well deserved people. - There is nothing called PROCESS. Seems like to get a PROCESS in place, they need another PROCESS. - Work is mostly on ADHOC basis (at times one gets paid for doing nothing or for a simple Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V - Insane). - GOALS set by your manager, at times really don't look like goals. Can, being in office for 9 hours called a GOAL? Filling your working hours on your time sheet is a GOAL? Really?!?!?! One will end up surfing on internet to find what does GOAL actually mean. Trust me! - There is no meaning for the term 'MID YEAR GOAL REVIEW' - basically nothing is reviewed and nothing is considered. And usually a mid year goals review happens in the end of the year, so that you get no chance to know what you have achieved and on what you have to buck up. In the end its said that ' Dude, you haven't performed', which is proportionate to the Hike you receive. GROW UP PLEASE ! - Be hear if you want to screw your vocab, ethics and lose your personal self. - If you are here, get used to few words, 'Udjust', ' May be next year', 'I don't know' etc etc. - Not recommended for a fresher. - Definitely not a place for people having bold/straight forward attitude. - Only the watered plants are watered always - Did you get me?? - Cost cutting at times leads not just to the cancellation of benefits for the employees but also extends to poor food quality at cafeteria. - Yeah, office probably seems to be a mini Andhra or mini Kerala. No offence. But lot of internal politics(Region specific). Better be a Politician than an IT professional. - Employees are not trained to maintain Professionalism - in fact most don't know what it means. - Static work most of the times - one will get bored easily.

title: Please dont join if you have other offers
pros: Wfh flexibility (need to be approved), travel benefits, company as a whole is planned well. Some of the teams are well maintained as managers are good. Free limited cheap biscuits, tea and coffee.
cons: Baniya ka dhukan like typical indian gov., no managerial skills for so called leadership team, more politics inside than the indian politics. Biased indian management, no growth for hard working people, no clarity of work. No job security. Company will restructure every 2 years and retain only old folks. So what ever level you are in, you are not safe.

title: Nurturing and engaging
pros: The team we have is great. People are supportive and warm, the inclusion and diversity is of utmost importance. We are rather a larger family, and you can find support everywhere. The annual Employee Satisfaction surveys are followed through with actions, looking for everyone's comfort zone. The variety of roles, given the size, is a nice plus and enhances carrier development.
cons: Being a very large company, the management style is it still conservative, and the changes are slow, especially at organization level. From the same reasons, locally speaking, there might be locations with higher employee satisfaction, versus other at the other hand, with very happy employees.

title: It's not what it used to be.
pros: Co-workers in hourly wage positions are for the most part dedicated and take pride in what they do. For these people, doing things right for the customer is of utmost importance.
cons: Poorly trained management. Best way to be promoted to a management position (and keep it)seems to be say "yes" to any and all ideas corporate throws out. New performance measurement programs take the concept of micro managing to a new level, with no insight from management as to actually how to improve performance.

title: Acquisition of HCL
pros: > Best at work life balance > Package and hike is descent >Good combo between QA & DEV team
cons: > Because of HCL Acquisition, 90% of the team has moved to HCL office and rest that are still with IM have not much have new in future > The best team of HR has already left IM due to uncertainty of future and rest does not look to be functioning efficiently > Its been a very non predictive and unsafe company now for employees with no road map ahead

title: Review Iron Mountain Cluj-Napoca
pros: The colleagues were very nice, and the work was not tough at all. If you were keeping up with the requirements, everything was alright.
cons: The work was quite boring. The bosses were stressed almost all the time. When I was telling them that I was leaving the company because I got a better job, the bosses were behaving badly towards you. You have to respect your breaks. you will have a problem if stay longer than 15 minutes, for example.

title: Treated as a 'Stepping Stone' Job.
pros: Stability, 07:30-4PM guaranteed hours. £300 bonus quarterly. Team working at the bottom is great, and a few team leaders.
cons: Low staff moral. No incentive to keep staff, instead, as if they are trying to drive them away. No overtime. Ever. If you have your coat on even 3 minutes before the end of your shift - expect to be told off like a school child. Hit your target or leave kind of attitude.

title: I used to respect Iron Mountain, now I would never, ever recommend anyone to work here.
pros: Pays the bills. Covers insurance.
cons: Unless you like having your 8hr work day tracked to the minute, do not work here. The company recently hired consultants who have now permanently implemented "Operator Logs" into the Corporate environment, across the entire company. Individuals (including accountants, CPAs, auditors, business support staff, etc) must record every minute of their day. Such categories on these "operator logs" include time spent in the bathroom, time spent on phonecalls, emails, meetings, etc. This information then feeds into all sorts of reports in which Management can track Productivity, Lost Time, Efficiency, etc. It's micromanagement to the Nth degree. I wish it on no-one.

title: Lost it's way
pros: The company does want to make a change. They are looking for ways to rely less on managing paper. The staff at times is very approachable.
cons: The management is still very top down. There is not much faith that the staff is capable. Instead, the style is to dictate an approach, then be surprised when the staff doesn't think on it's own.

title: You are just a number
pros: Decent benefits and bonus plan (if you are in management).
cons: You are just a number at IM, they have strict targets that you must achieve and they do not care about any barriers that may impede the achievement of them. There is little opportunity to advance as they have outsourced every department they could, and there is very little movement in management. They allow management to abuse employees.

title: Stable Company but salary and advancement opportunities not there
pros: Some management very understanding that you have a life outside of the company.
cons: Senior Management not really knowledgeable about responsibilities of role. No clear advancement path. Lots of reorganization going on now.

title: Easy money if you can deal with bullying supervisor
pros: Easy work. Relaxed environment.
cons: Bullying supervisor would rather leave rude post it notes on my desk than speak to me face to face. Cold air conditioned environment. No key fobs to get around the building. No log in to use the computer. Always relying on other staff to buzz me in and out of the warehouse and log in my computer.

title: rose tinted glasses
pros: some good people work there
cons: ran on the principle that cutting costs is an acceptable way of making profits even if it means not fixing things is in violation of one of our key codes of conduct . in other words if it costs iron mountain money lets not do it. employee training is a joke.

title: Proof that cutting your way to growth doesn’t work!
pros: Talented and professional people that genuinely care and as a result give 18 hour days to make it all work.
cons: 18 hour days are now the requirement to make it work.

title: Read this before joining
pros: - Big company name - Free parking for employees in Brisbane
cons: - Next to nothing pay rate (lowest in the industry) - Systems are very outdated - No trainer or training material - Everything is manual - The IT systems are the worst you will ever work with - No fun days or incentive

title: not sure where IRM is going...
pros: big company name and reputation
cons: management changes, integration nightmares, poor morale, a lot of nervous tension and uncertainty

title: If you are looking for a company where hard work and dedication is valued, look elsewhere...
pros: The company offers decent benefits and a generous vacation package, especially if you are willing to commit long term service.
cons: There is rampant favoritism that goes on, from the way policies are implemented to promotions given. The favorites get away with a lot; however, if you are the unlucky majority, watch your back because you will surely find a knife in it. The open door policy is a joke. Some supervisors that work here are the most unprofessional people you will ever meet. Not only will they NOT lead by example, but they will divulge confidential information about you to your peers, take shortcuts and point fingers when something goes wrong, as well as blatantly lie. Apparently, checking game scores online, sleeping in the office, and other activities unrelated to the job is okay for supervisors to do during company time, but not okay for the staff. Be ready to be micromanaged! If you have good work ethic, care about the quality of work you produce and the customers you serve, your efforts may prove to be fruitless. You will become frustrated because you do not have your boss' support and you will eventually become demotivated. Opportunities are slim. No wonder why there are some many lack luster performers and such a high turnover rate!

title: A company going through a soul search.
pros: The opportunity to learn about many different businesses through interaction with clients.
cons: It is still a very male-dominated organization and not much has been done to explore diversity. Many employees in management began their careers right out of high school and have limited exposure to other management styles and business models. It still has an insular feel about it.

title: Global MNC and market leader, plagued with silo and layered structure
pros: Global leader in information management. Solidified its position as #1 after acquiring Recall #2. Plenty of strong leaders in the company, be it in global or regional capacity, and also local market leaders. Good place to develop leadership skills through experience and observation.
cons: Best practice sharing could been a lot better between markets and regions. Do it proactively and regularly. Will take some time to breakaway from its physical record management association to emerge as a digital company who handles end-to-end information management and governance. Structures can be too silo at certain functions. Lack collaboration inter-region.

title: A company with exciting prospect but fallen in the wrong hands (Consider this as a very genuine review)
pros: - The nature of business is very unique and there is a lot of scope to learn on how Iron Mountain works. - If you are lucky and you get a dotted line reporting to a manager who is based out of North America who is also known as a functional manager in Iron Mountain, mostly you are safe from being micro managed. There is also a good amount of flexibility and work from home options based on your job role and your manager. - I like the open door policy in this company which helps you to get in touch with a lot of senior leaders and learn from them on many aspects. I believe this brings in a lot of visibility and exposure to an employee who is willing to learn and implement on the work. This though is still not being appreciated a lot in the Bangalore office. - There are good opportunities to learn which is solely based on your manager and the systems you work in here. - The pantry has a few goodies with free beverages, bread and cookies for quick bites. Though the company is slowly cutting down on all free items within the pantry.
cons: ider this as a very genuine review)

title: Like Fleet Admiral Gial Ackbar said: "IT´S A TRAP!"
pros: It is a multinational Company; It is well-known; Salary is quite interesting (but hold your horses until you read the rest); Standard benefits and work remote.
cons: Like the mermaid´s siren song...all those pros, good salary, benefits...it looks good, don´t you think? Well...it took me one week to realize that the Company is a real mess and the general feeling on behalf of management is that they really feel lost as well. They just throw scope to you and you have to figure out the rest: the people, the processes, the documentation, everything. Except with deadlines and meetings, of course.

title: IM is the place to be if you do not have a life outside of work
pros: The employees on the front line are incredibly committed and dedicated to the customer. The benefit package is competitive, yet the compensation provided does not equal the true value of the position and effort needed to succeed.
cons: Over the last 12 months, the culture at Iron Mountain has changed from one of employee empowerment to one of micromanagement. The change in sr. leadership has not been a positive influence throughout the organization and there is huge disconnect from corporate to the field. While change is imperative to remain competitve, the changes being implemented are not customer or employee-centric

title: Working at Iron Mountain
pros: Though I had worked for short period, I found that the working atmosphere was good with cheerful colleagues and nice supervisor. Humourous and serious working natures of the people were seen and it was like a family together. There was no need of buying coffee or tea during breaks and it was free self preparing. Honesty among colleagues was also witnessed as my mobile was returned to me when I forgot to pickup after keeping aside in the toilet.
cons: No significant cons were noticed. Timely replenishments of the ingredients for coffee or tea are desirable.

title: From outstanding at the beginning to worsening at the end
pros: -Lots of work -Met many people from other countries, led regional projects -Learned and did lots of innovation -Enjoyed all my years before February 2017
cons: -Began to layoff colleagues based on efficiencies and to cause difficulties to customers -Outsourced IT and technology functions and caused service to deteriorate against expectations -Lack of future perspective, limitations of growth.

title: A Mixed Bag
pros: The company has many talented people who are genuinely focused on the customer. They have an excellent track record for safety and a strong history of protecting customer assets. The company invests in its technology and has recently undergone a massive effort to update a lot of core infrastructure. They have a genuine commitment to ESG , Safety and Security. Pay is middle of the road, with decent benefits, including rrsp matching and a discounted employee stock purchase program
cons: Very siloed environment, resulting in underinformed decision-making. Changes are made with little to no input from those who will be tasked with implementing them. In the last year or two the company has been focused solely on increasing revenue, which is not a bad thing, but not at the cost of everything else. The company still has not addressed the long-standing customer service and billing issues and dismiss any concerns raised that this creates issues for sales to increase their share of wallet with existing customers. Right now most of the "growth" is being achieved through 40% + price increases for those same customers. Pricing is handed down from finance and any changes require multiple layers of approval and justification, most of which is not approved. Committment to DE&I is hit or miss. They have a chief diversity officer, but so far she hasn't really done anything substantial and the employee resource groups have done most of the heavy lifting in recent years. While pay is ok, the incentive (bonus plan) for CSMs has 3 components, but only 1 of which is in your direct control. The company also says they have a commitment to close the gender pay gap, but at a future date (2025 was the last target I am aware of)

title: Looked like a great opportunity coming in the door but things continually went down hill.
pros: Adequate benefit package, fairly priced. Bridged vacation time from old employer. Good training and knowledge sharing as well as access to industry certifications. If you were willing to move there were opportunities for advancement. For the most part worked with individuals (front line employees/supervisors) that cared about doing a good job. I learned a lot there and am thankful for the experience in that it prepared me well for my next position in relationship management.
cons: Too much old school micro-management. Management continually made moves to squeeze cost out of the department, first by deleting variable compensation while giving only negligible salary increases to compensate for the loss of income. Of course they still wanted us to "sell" what we were previously compensated on. Then continually kept reducing staff but responsibility and expectations kept increasing, never really saw a 40 hour week unless there was a holiday. Regularly spent 50-60 hours per week getting the work done. Not much support from direct manager when there was one, they couldn't keep a manager for very long. The way they are cutting costs I wouldn't be surprised if the balance sheet is being prepped for a sale. Also surprised at the amount of unethical behavior towards customers and their contract terms.

title: Actions Speak Louder than Words
pros: Good benefit package; great mid-management and front line employees
cons: Although Iron Mountain speaks a LOT about supporting a diverse work environment and equitable opportunities for all employees regardless of race or gender they continue to act in a way that COMPLETELY undermines their espoused values. New appointment of Diversity & Inclusion team may change things over time but only time will tell. For now, as recently as July an EVP proudly announced his new, all white male leadership team. Further, their PAC continues to support politicians who vocally and actively support racist and misogynistic ideals

title: Great culture, opportunities, transforming business
pros: Great culture, flexible working, remote for all marketing roles globally but still feel like part of a wider team. CMO is very transparent and supportive, he really seems to care. Lots of transformation happening which brings about opportunities to grow and learn or even change roles. Strong ESG practices. Good communication about what's going on the business.
cons: Marketing still trying to stamp its place as a revenue generator but making big leaps. It's a really big complex organisation which is a lot to get your head around.

title: Everyone is saying the same thing, why is there no change?
pros: Nice, professional, and caring employees.
cons: I hope that someone with a “C” in their title at IM is responsible for reading these open and candid reviews from their employees on this site. For the most part, the message remains the same, across the World, not just the USA. UN-FAIRNESS…something so easy to fix that would make such a difference with your employees, which will result in the $$ Numbers $$ you are looking to achieve. VP and above should be measured on employee development and advancement within their teams. An outside applicant should not receive a position that qualified internal candidates apply for and meet all needs of the position. There is no promotion in IM. You can work hard, produce great results, and receive a 2% annual increase, and “you should be thankful you have a job.” This is a two-way street between an employer and an employee, you are losing valuable and dedicated employees. I have personally witnessed some of the most corrupt and unethical decisions, employees “placed” in positions that never existed, absolutely no consideration of internal employees, no advancement opportunities. I was told once “this is not the old IM”, that is the truest statement I have heard to date. What was wrong with the old IM, where decisions were fair and earned, where you paid your employees their value? You have to stop the favoritism and corruption before the Company declines any further. Look at what you have, and consider what you could end up with! This many posters/employees cannot be wrong, or exaggerating the point. Please, if you really care, thicken up the skin and deal with this issue, read the posts from “your employees”.
